1.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, look southward, preach toward the south, and prophesy against the forest of the southern land.

3.verse: Hear the word of the LORD! you shall say to the southern forest. Thus says the Lord GOD: See! I am kindling a fire in you that shall devour all trees, the green as well as the dry. The blazing flame shall not be quenched, but from south to north every face shall be scorched by it.

4.verse: Everyone shall see that I, the LORD, have kindled it, and it shall not be quenched.

5.verse: But I said, "Alas! Lord GOD, they say to me, 'Is not this the one who is forever spinning parables?'"

6.verse: Then the word of the LORD came to me:

7.verse: Son of man, look toward Jerusalem, preach against their sanctuary, and prophesy against the land of Israel,

8.verse: saying to the land of Israel: Thus says the LORD: See! I am coming at you; I will draw my sword from its sheath and cut off from you the virtuous and the wicked.

9.verse: Thus my sword shall leave its sheath against everyone from south to north,

10.verse: and everyone shall know that I, the LORD, have drawn my sword from its sheath, and it shall not be sheathed again.

11.verse: As for you, son of man, groan! with shattered strength groan bitterly while they look on.

12.verse: And when they ask you, "Why are you groaning?", you shall say: Because of a report; when it comes every heart shall fail, every hand shall fall helpless, every spirit shall be daunted, and every knee shall run with water. See, it is coming, it is here! says the Lord GOD.

13.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

14.verse: Son of man, prophesy! say: Thus says the LORD: A sword, a sword has been sharpened, a sword, a sword has been burnished:

15.verse: To work slaughter has it been sharpened, to flash lightning has it been burnished. Why should I now withdraw it? You have spurned the rod and every judgment!

16.verse: I have given it over to the burnisher that he might hold it in his hand, A sword sharpened and burnished to be put in the hand of a slayer.

17.verse: Cry out and wail, son of man, for it is destined for my people; It is for all the princes of Israel, victims of the sword with my people. Therefore, slap your thigh,

18.verse: for the sword has been tested; and why should it not be so? says the Lord GOD, since you have spurned the rod.

19.verse: As for you, son of man, prophesy, brushing one hand against the other: While the sword is doubled and tripled, this sword of slaughter, This great sword of slaughter which threatens all around,

20.verse: That every heart may tremble; for many will be the fallen. At all their gates I have appointed the sword for slaughter, Fashioned to flash lightning, burnished for slaughter.

21.verse: Cleave to the right! destroy! to the left! wherever your edge is turned.

22.verse: Then I, too, shall brush one hand against the other and wreak my fury. I, the LORD, have spoken.

23.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

24.verse: Son of man, make for yourself two roads over which the sword of the king of Babylon can come. Both roads shall lead out from the same land. Then put a signpost at the head of each road,

25.verse: so that the sword can come to Rabbah of the Ammonites or to Judah's capital, Jerusalem.

26.verse: For at the fork where the two roads divide stands the king of Babylon, divining; he has shaken the arrows, inquired of the teraphim, inspected the liver.

27.verse: In his right hand is the divining arrow marked "Jerusalem," bidding him to give the order for slaying, to raise his voice in the battle cry, to post battering rams at the gates, to cast up a ramp, to build a siege tower.

28.verse: In their eyes this is but a lying oracle; yet they are bound by the oaths they have sworn, and the arrow taken in hand marks their guilt.

29.verse: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: Because you have drawn attention to your guilt, with your crimes laid bare and your sinfulness in all your wicked deeds revealed (because attention has been drawn to you), you shall be taken in hand.

30.verse: And as for you, depraved and wicked prince of Israel, whose day is coming when your life of crime will be ended,

31.verse: thus says the Lord GOD: Off with the turban and away with the crown! Nothing shall be as it was! Up with the low and down with the high!

32.verse: Twisted, twisted, twisted will I leave it; it shall not be the same until he comes who has the claim against the city; and to him I will hand it over.

33.verse: As for you, son of man, prophesy: Thus says the Lord GOD against the Ammonites and their insults: A sword, a sword is drawn for slaughter, burnished to consume and to flash lightning,

34.verse: because you planned with false visions and lying divinations to lay it on the necks of depraved and wicked men whose day has come when their crimes are at an end.

35.verse: Return it to its sheath! In the place where you were created, in the land of your origin, I will judge you.

36.verse: I will pour out my indignation upon you, breathing my fiery wrath upon you, I will hand you over to ravaging men, artisans of destruction.

37.verse: You shall be fuel for the fire, your blood shall flow throughout the land. You shall not be remembered, for I, the LORD, have spoken.

annotations.1: [2-4] The southern kingdom, Judah, is likened to a forest about to be burned; cf Jeremiah 21:14.
annotations.2: [8] Cut off from you the virtuous and the wicked: a more complete devastation of Jerusalem than that described in Ezekiel 9:6
annotations.3: [12] A report: the news of the fall of Jerusalem; cf Ezekiel 33:21- 22
annotations.4: [17] Slap your thigh: a gesture signifying grief and dread
annotations.5: [22] Brush one hand against the other: a gesture signifying the rejection of responsibility; cf Ezekiel 22:13; Numbers 24:10
annotations.6: [26] Three forms of divination are mentioned: arrow divination, consisting in the use of differently marked arrows extracted or shaken from a case at random; the consultation of the teraphim or household idols, and liver divination, scrutiny of the configurations of the livers of newly slaughtered animals, a common form of divination in Mesopotamia
annotations.7: [27-28] An arrow marked "Jerusalem" is picked out, which marks the guilt of the city's inhabitants for having broken their oath of allegiance to Nebuchadnezzar
annotations.8: [33] (33-37) In the preceding section Nebuchadnezzar is represented as deciding whether to attack Jerusalem or Rabbath-Ammon. As it happened, Jerusalem was chosen for attack; later, however, the Chaldeans also invaded Ammon. The present oracle against Ammon is inserted here, rather than in Ezekial 25-32, in order to complement the oracle against Jerusalem

1.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, turn toward Gog (the land of Magog), the chief prince of Meshech and Tubal, and prophesy against him:

3.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: See! I am coming at you, Gog, chief prince of Meshech and Tubal.

4.verse: I will lead you forth with all your army, horses and riders all handsomely outfitted, a great horde with bucklers and shields, all of them carrying swords:

5.verse: Persia, Cush, and Put with them (all with shields and helmets),

6.verse: Gomer with all its troops, Beth-togarmah from the recesses of the north with all its troops, many peoples with you.

7.verse: Prepare yourself, be ready, you and all your horde assembled about you, and be at my disposal.

8.verse: After many days you will be mustered (in the last years you will come) against a nation which has survived the sword, which has been assembled from many peoples (on the mountains of Israel which were long a ruin), which has been brought forth from among the peoples and all of whom now dwell in security.

9.verse: You shall come up like a sudden storm, advancing like a cloud to cover the earth, you and all your troops and the many peoples with you.

10.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: At that time thoughts shall arise in your mind, and you shall devise an evil scheme:

11.verse: "I will go up against a land of open villages and attack the peaceful people who are living in security, all of them living without walls, having neither bars nor gates,

12.verse: to plunder and pillage, turning my hand against the ruins that were repeopled and against a people gathered from the nations, a people concerned with cattle and goods, who dwell at the navel of the earth."

13.verse: Sheba and Dedan, the merchants of Tarshish and all her young lions shall ask you: "Is it for plunder that you have come? Is it for pillage that you have summoned your horde, to carry off silver and gold, to take away cattle and goods, to seize much plunder?"

17.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: It is of you that I spoke in ancient times through my servants, the prophets of Israel, who prophesied in those days that I would bring you against them.

18.verse: But on that day, the day when Gog invades the land of Israel, says the Lord GOD, my fury shall be aroused. In my anger

19.verse: and in my jealousy, in my fiery wrath, I swear: On that day there shall be a great shaking upon the land of Israel.

20.verse: Before me shall tremble the fish of the sea and the birds of the air, the beasts of the field and all the reptiles that crawl upon the ground, and all men who are on the land. Mountains shall be overturned, and cliffs shall tumble, and every wall shall fall to the ground.

21.verse: Against him I will summon every terror, says the Lord GOD, every man's sword against his brother. I will hold judgment with him in pestilence and bloodshed;

22.verse: flooding rain and hailstones, fire and brimstone, I will rain upon him, upon his troops, and upon the many peoples with him.

23.verse: I will prove my greatness and holiness and make myself known in the sight of many nations; thus they shall know that I am the LORD.

14.verse: Therefore prophesy, son of man, and say to Gog: Thus says the Lord GOD: When my people Israel are dwelling in security, will you not bestir yourself

15.verse: and come from your home in the recesses of the north, you and many peoples with you, all mounted on horses, a great horde and a mighty army?

16.verse: You shall come up against my people Israel like a cloud covering the land. In the last days I will bring you against my land, that the nations may know of me, when in their sight I prove my holiness through you, O Gog.

annotations.1: [ 38:1- 39:20] These three oracles against Gog may refer either to a specific foreign invasion in the future, or to the apocalyptic struggle between good and evil at the end of time. By some they are ascribed to a later author than Ezekiel, who lived after the exile and the return to Palestine.
annotations.2: [2] Gog: the name is almost certainly a symbolic one taken from that of Gyges, king of Lydia, whether or not the prophet has a specific person in mind. The gloss Magog may be an Akkadian expression, mat-Gog, "the land of Gog." Meshech and Tubal, as well as Gomer and Beth-togarmah ( Ezekiel 38:6), were countries around the Black Sea, the northernmost countries known to the Hebrews: the north (cf also Ezekiel 38:22(15)) was the traditional direction from which invasion was expected; cf Jeremiah 1:13-15
annotations.3: [12] Who dwell at the navel of the earth: the people of Israel (cf Ezekiel 38:15(18); Ezekiel 5:5). Many ancient peoples spoke of their own homelands as "the navel," that is, the center of the earth

1.verse: On the first day of the third month in the eleventh year, the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, say to Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, and to his hordes: What are you like in your greatness?

3.verse: Behold, a cypress (cedar) in Lebanon, beautiful of branch, lofty of stature, amid the very clouds lifted its crest.

4.verse: Waters made it grow, the abyss made it flourish, sending its rivers round where it was planted, turning its streams to all the trees of the field.

5.verse: Thus it grew taller than every other tree of the field, and longer of branch because of the abundant water.

6.verse: In its boughs nested all the birds of the air, under its branches all beasts of the field gave birth, in its shade dwelt numerous peoples of every race.

7.verse: It became beautiful and stately in its spread of foliage, for its roots were turned toward abundant water.

8.verse: The cedars in the garden of God were not its equal, nor could the fir trees match its boughs, Neither were the plane trees like it for branches; no tree in the garden of God matched its beauty.

9.verse: I made it beautiful, with much foliage, the envy of all Eden's trees in the garden of God.

10.verse: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: Because it became lofty in stature, raising its crest among the clouds, and because it became proud in heart at its height,

11.verse: I have handed it over to the mightiest of the nations, which has dealt with it in keeping with its wickedness. I humiliated it.

12.verse: Foreigners, the most ruthless of the nations, cut it down and left it on the mountains. Its foliage was brought low in all the valleys, its branches lay broken in all the ravines of the land, and all the peoples of the land withdrew from its shade, abandoning it.

13.verse: On its fallen trunk rested all the birds of the air, and by its branches were all the beasts of the field.

14.verse: Thus no tree may grow lofty in stature or raise its crest among the clouds; no tree fed by water may stand by itself in its loftiness. For all of them are destined for death, for the land below, For the company of mortals, those who go down into the pit.

15.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: On the day he went down to the nether world I made the abyss close up over him; I stopped its streams so that the deep waters were held back. I cast gloom over Lebanon because of him, so that all the trees in the land drooped on his account.

16.verse: At the crash of his fall I made the nations rock, when I cast him down to the nether world with those who go down into the pit. In the land below, all Eden's trees were consoled, Lebanon's choice and best, all that were fed by water.

17.verse: They too have come down with him to the nether world, to those slain by the sword; those who dwelt in his shade are dispersed among the nations.

18.verse: Which was your equal in glory or size among the trees of Eden? Yet you have been brought down with the trees of Eden to the land below. You shall lie with the uncircumcised, with those slain by the sword. Such are Pharaoh and all his hordes, says the Lord GOD.

annotations.1: [1] The first day of the third month in the eleventh year: June 21, 587 B.C.

1.verse: Son of man, stand up! I wish to speak with you.

2.verse: As he spoke to me, spirit entered into me and set me on my feet, and I heard the one who was speaking

3.verse: say to me: Son of man, I am sending you to the Israelites, rebels who have rebelled against me; they and their fathers have revolted against me to this very day.

4.verse: Hard of face and obstinate of heart are they to whom I am sending you. But you shall say to them: Thus says the Lord GOD!

5.verse: And whether they heed or resist - for they are a rebellious house - they shall know that a prophet has been among them.

6.verse: But as for you, son of man, fear neither them nor their words when they contradict you and reject you, and when you sit on scorpions. Neither fear their words nor be dismayed at their looks, for they are a rebellious house.

7.verse: (But speak my words to them, whether they heed or resist, for they are rebellious.)

8.verse: As for you, son of man, obey me when I speak to you: be not rebellious like this house of rebellion, but open your mouth and eat what I shall give you.

9.verse: It was then I saw a hand stretched out to me, in which was a written scroll

10.verse: which he unrolled before me. It was covered with writing front and back, and written on it was: Lamentation and wailing and woe!

annotations.1: [1] Son of man: a formal way of saying simply "man"; God's habitual way of addressing the prophet throughout this book. Probably the title is used to emphasize the separation of the divine and the human.
annotations.2: [2] Spirit: vital power, coming from God, which enables the prophet to hear the word of God; cf Ezekiel 8:3; 9:24; 11:1
annotations.3: [6] When you sit on scorpions: the prophet must be prepared for the bitterest opposition

1.verse: Then he led me to the gate which faces the east,

2.verse: and there I saw the glory of the God of Israel coming from the east. I heard a sound like the roaring of many waters, and the earth shone with his glory.

3.verse: The vision was like that which I had seen when he came to destroy the city, and like that which I had seen by the river Chebar. I fell prone

4.verse: as the glory of the LORD entered the temple by way of the gate which faces the east,

5.verse: but spirit lifted me up and brought me to the inner court. And I saw that the temple was filled with the glory of the LORD.

6.verse: Then I heard someone speaking to me from the temple, while the man stood beside me.

7.verse: The voice said to me: Son of man, this is where my throne shall be, this is where I will set the soles of my feet; here I will dwell among the Israelites forever. Never again shall they and their kings profane my holy name with their harlotries and with the corpses of their kings (their high places).

8.verse: When they placed their threshold against my threshold and their doorpost next to mine, so that only a wall was between us, they profaned my holy name by their abominable deeds; therefore I consumed them in my wrath.

9.verse: From now on they shall put far from me their harlotry and the corpses of their kings, and I will dwell in their midst forever.

10.verse: As for you, son of man, describe the temple to the house of Israel (that they may be ashamed of their sins), both its measurements and its design;

11.verse: (and if they are ashamed of all that they have done,) make known to them the form and design of the temple, its exits and entrances, all its statutes and laws; write these down for them to see, that they may carefully observe all its laws and statutes.

12.verse: This is the law of the temple: its whole surrounding area on the mountain top shall be most sacred.

13.verse: These were the measurements of the altar in cubits of one cubit plus a handbreadth. Its base was one cubit high and one cubit deep, with a rim around its edges of one span. The height of the altar itself was as follows:

14.verse: from its base at the bottom up to the lower edge it was two cubits high, and this ledge was one cubit deep; from the lower to the upper ledge it was four cubits high, and this ledge also was one cubit deep;

15.verse: the hearth of the altar was four cubits high, and extending from the top of the hearth were the four horns of the altar.

16.verse: The hearth was a square: twelve cubits long and twelve cubits wide.

17.verse: The upper ledge was also a square: fourteen cubits long and fourteen cubits wide. The lower ledge, likewise a square, was sixteen cubits long and sixteen cubits wide, with a half-cubit rim surrounding it. And there was a base of one cubit all around. The steps of the altar face the east.

18.verse: Then he said to me: Son of man, thus says the Lord GOD: These are the statutes for the altar when it is set up for the offering of holocausts upon it and for the sprinkling of blood against it.

19.verse: Give a young bull as a sin offering to the priests, the Levites who are of the line of Zadok, who draw near me to minister to me, says the Lord GOD.

20.verse: Take some of its blood and put it on the four horns of the altar, and on the four corners of the ledge, and on the rim all around. Thus you shall purify it and make atonement for it.

21.verse: Then take the bull of the sin offering, which is to be burnt in a designated part of the temple, outside the sanctuary.

22.verse: On the second day present an unblemished he-goat as a sin offering, to purify the altar as was done with the bull.

23.verse: When you have finished the purification, bring an unblemished young bull and an unblemished ram from the flock,

24.verse: and present them before the LORD; the priests shall strew salt on them and offer them to the LORD as holocausts.

25.verse: Daily for seven days you shall offer a he-goat as a sin offering, and a young bull and a ram from the flock, all unblemished, shall be offered

26.verse: for seven days. Thus atonement shall be made for the altar, and it shall be purified and dedicated.

27.verse: And when these days are over, from the eighth day on, the priests shall offer your holocausts and peace offerings on the altar. Then I will accept you, says the Lord GOD.

annotations.1: [8] They placed their threshold against my threshold: the preexilic temple and the royal palace belonged to the same complex of buildings, and this physical proximity was reflected in the use made of the temple by kings like Ahaz and Manasseh, who treated it as their private chapel for pagan rites. In the new Israel the temple is free, even physically, from civil jurisdiction; cf Ezekiel 45:7-8.
annotations.2: [13] The altar: of holocausts, standing in the inner court of the temple area; cf Ezekiel 40:47

1.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, you live in the midst of a rebellious house; they have eyes to see but do not see, and ears to hear but do not hear, for they are a rebellious house.

3.verse: Now, son of man, during the day while they are looking on, prepare your baggage as though for exile, and again while they are looking on, migrate from where you live to another place; perhaps they will see that they are a rebellious house.

4.verse: You shall bring out your baggage like an exile in the daytime while they are looking on; in the evening, again while they are looking on, you shall go out like one of those driven into exile;

5.verse: while they look on, dig a hole in the wall and pass through it;

6.verse: while they look on, shoulder the burden and set out in the darkness; cover your face that you may not see the land, for I have made you a sign for the house of Israel.

7.verse: I did as I was told. During the day I brought out my baggage as though it were that of an exile, and at evening I dug a hole through the wall with my hand and, while they looked on, set out in the darkness, shouldering my burden.

8.verse: Then, in the morning, the word of the LORD came to me:

9.verse: Son of man, did not the house of Israel, that rebellious house, ask you what you were doing?

10.verse: Tell them: Thus says the Lord GOD: This oracle concerns Jerusalem and the whole house of Israel within it.

11.verse: I am a sign for you: as I have done, so shall it be done to them; as captives they shall go into exile.

12.verse: The prince who is among them shall shoulder his burden and set out in darkness, going through a hole that he has dug in the wall, and covering his face lest he be seen by anyone.

13.verse: But I will spread my net over him, and he shall be taken in my snare. I will bring him to Babylon, into the land of the Chaldeans - but he shall not see it - and there he shall die.

14.verse: All his retinue, his aides, and his troops I will scatter in every direction, and pursue them with the sword.

15.verse: Then shall they know that I am the LORD, when I disperse them among the nations and scatter them over foreign lands.

16.verse: Yet I will leave a few of them to escape the sword, famine and pestilence, so that they may tell of all their abominations among the nations to which they will come; thus they shall know that I am the LORD.

17.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

18.verse: Son of man, eat your bread trembling, and drink your water shaking with anxiety.

19.verse: Then say to the people of the land: Thus says the Lord GOD of the inhabitants of Jerusalem (to the land of Israel): They shall eat their bread in anxiety and drink their water in horror, that their land may be emptied of the violence of all its inhabitants that now fills it.

20.verse: Inhabited cities shall be in ruins, and the land shall be a waste; thus you shall know that I am the LORD.

21.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

22.verse: Son of man, what is this proverb that you have in the land of Israel: "The days drag on, and no vision ever comes to anything"?

23.verse: Say to them therefore: Thus says the Lord GOD: I will put an end to this proverb; they shall never quote it again in Israel. Rather, say to them: The days are at hand, and also the fulfillment of every vision.

25.verse: Whatever I speak is final, and it shall be done without further delay. In your days, rebellious house, whatever I speak I will bring about, says the Lord GOD.

24.verse: There shall no longer be any false visions or deceitful divinations within the house of Israel, because it is I, the LORD, who will speak.

26.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

27.verse: Son of man, listen to the house of Israel saying, "The vision he sees is a long way off; he prophesies of the distant future!"

28.verse: Say to them therefore: Thus says the Lord GOD: None of my words shall be delayed any longer; whatever I speak is final, and it shall be done, says the Lord GOD.

annotations.1: [5] Dig a hole in the wall: the exiles are to leave Jerusalem through the broken walls of the ruined city.
annotations.2: [13] But he shall not see it: Zedekiah was blinded by Nebuchadnezzar before being deported to Babylonia; cf 2 Kings 25:7
annotations.3: [22,27] These words were used against Ezekiel because of the apparent failure of his prophecies; cf Jeremiah 20:7-9

1.verse: Then he led me north to the outer court, bringing me to some chambers on the north that lay across the free area and which were also across from the building.

2.verse: Their length was a hundred cubits on the north side, and they were fifty cubits wide.

3.verse: Across the twenty cubits of the inner court and the pavement of the outer court, there were three parallel rows of them on different levels.

4.verse: In front of the chambers, to the inside, was a walk ten cubits broad and a wall of one cubit; but the entrances of the chambers were on the north.

5.verse: The outermost chambers were the lowest, for the system of levels set them at a level lower than the closest chambers and those in between;

6.verse: for they were in three rows and had no foundations to conform with the foundations of the courts, therefore they were on a lower terrace of the ground than the closest and the middle chambers.

7.verse: On the far side there was a wall running parallel to the chambers along the outer court; its length before these chambers was fifty cubits,

8.verse: for the length of the chambers belonging to the outer court was fifty cubits, but along its entire length the wall measured one hundred cubits.

9.verse: Below these chambers there was the way in from the east, so that one could enter from the outer court

10.verse: where the wall of the court began. To the south along the side of the free area and the building there were also chambers,

11.verse: before which was a passage. These looked like the chambers to the north, just as long and just as wide, with the same exits and plan and entrances.

12.verse: Below the chambers to the south there was an entrance at the beginning of the way which led to the back wall, by which one could enter from the east.

13.verse: He said to me, "The north and south chambers which border on the free area are the sanctuary chambers; here the priests who draw near to the LORD shall eat the most sacred meals, and here they shall keep the most sacred offerings: cereal offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings; for it is a holy place.

14.verse: When the priests have once entered, they shall not leave the holy place for the outer court until they have left here the clothing in which they ministered, for it is holy. They shall put on other garments, and then approach the place destined for the people."

15.verse: When he had finished measuring the inner temple area, he brought me out by way of the gate which faces east and measured all the limits of the court.

16.verse: He measured the east side: five hundred cubits by his measuring rod. Then he turned

17.verse: and measured the north side: five hundred cubits by the measuring rod. He turned

18.verse: to the south and measured five hundred cubits by the measuring rod.

19.verse: Then he turned to the west and measured five hundred cubits by the measuring rod.

20.verse: Thus he measured it in the four directions, five hundred cubits long and five hundred cubits wide. It was surrounded by a wall, to separate the sacred from the profane.

annotations.1: [5-6] The three rows of identical chambers, since they rested on different ground levels, necessarily had roofs on correspondingly different levels.
annotations.2: [13] The function of these chambers is explained again in Ezekiel 46:19-20

1.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: You, son of man, would you judge, would you judge the bloody city? Then make known all her abominations,

3.verse: and say: Thus says the Lord GOD: Woe to the city which sheds blood within herself so that her time has come, and which has made idols for her own defilement.

4.verse: By the blood which you shed you have been made guilty, and with the idols you made you have become defiled; you have brought on your day, so that the end of your years has come. Therefore I make you an object of scorn to the nations and a laughingstock to all foreign lands.

5.verse: Those near you and those far off shall deride you because of your foul reputation and your great perversity.

6.verse: See! the princes of Israel, family by family, are in you only for bloodshed.

7.verse: Within you, father and mother are despised; in your midst, they extort from the resident alien; within you, they oppress orphans and widows.

8.verse: What is holy to me you have spurned, and my sabbaths you have desecrated.

9.verse: There are those in you who slander to cause bloodshed; within you are those who feast on the mountains; in your midst are those who do lewd things.

10.verse: In you are those who uncover the nakedness of their fathers, and in you those who coerce women in their menstrual period.

11.verse: There are those in you who do abominable things with the wives of their neighbors, men who defile their daughters-in-law by incest, men who coerce their sisters, the daughters of their own fathers.

12.verse: There are those in you who take bribes to shed blood. You exact interest and usury; you despoil your neighbors violently; and me you have forgotten, says the Lord GOD.

13.verse: See, I am brushing one hand against the other because of the unjust profits you have made and because of the blood shed in your midst.

14.verse: Can your heart remain firm, will your hands be strong, in the days when I deal with you? I, the LORD, have spoken, and I will act.

15.verse: I will disperse you among the nations and scatter you over foreign lands, so that I may purge your uncleanness.

16.verse: In you I will allow myself to be profaned in the eyes of the nations; thus you shall know that I am the LORD.

17.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

18.verse: Son of man, the house of Israel has become dross for me. All of them are bronze and tin, iron and lead (in the midst of a furnace): dross from silver have they become.

19.verse: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: Because all of you have become dross, therefore I must gather you together within Jerusalem.

20.verse: Just as silver, bronze, iron, lead, and tin are gathered into a furnace and smelted in the roaring flames, so I will gather you together in my furious wrath, put you in, and smelt you.

21.verse: When I have assembled you, I will blast you with the fire of my anger and smelt you with it.

22.verse: You shall be smelted by it just as silver is smelted in a furnace. Thus you shall know that I, the LORD, have poured out my fury on you.

23.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

24.verse: Son of man, say to her: You are a land unrained on (that is, not rained on) at the time of my fury.

25.verse: Her princes are like roaring lions that tear prey; they devour people, seizing their wealth and precious things, and make widows of many within her.

26.verse: Her priests violate my law and profane what is holy to me; they do not distinguish between the sacred and the profane, nor teach the difference between the unclean and the clean; they pay no attention to my sabbaths, so that I have been profaned in their midst.

27.verse: Her nobles within her are like wolves that tear prey, shedding blood and destroying lives to get unjust gain.

28.verse: Her prophets cover them with whitewash, pretending to visions that are false and performing lying divinations, saying, "Thus says the Lord GOD," although the LORD has not spoken.

29.verse: The people of the land practice extortion and commit robbery; they afflict the poor and the needy, and oppress the resident alien without justice.

30.verse: Thus I have searched among them for someone who could build a wall or stand in the breach before me to keep me from destroying the land; but I found no one.

31.verse: Therefore I have poured out my fury upon them; with my fiery wrath I have consumed them; I have brought down their conduct upon their heads, says the Lord GOD.

1.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, turn toward the mountains of Israel, and prophesy against them:

3.verse: Mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Lord GOD. Thus says the Lord GOD (to the mountains and hills, the ravines and valleys): See, I am bringing a sword against you, and I will destroy your high places.

4.verse: Your altars shall be laid waste, your incense stands shall be broken, and I will cast down your slain ones before your idols;

5.verse: I will scatter their bones all around your altars.

6.verse: In all your dwelling places cities shall be made desolate and high places laid waste, so that your altars will be made desolate and laid waste, your idols broken and removed, and your incense stands smashed to bits.

7.verse: (The slain shall fall in your midst, and you shall know that I am the LORD.

8.verse: I have warned you.) When some of your people have escaped to other nations from the sword, and have been scattered over the foreign lands,

9.verse: then those who have escaped will remember me among the nations to which they have been exiled, after I have broken their adulterous hearts that turned away from me (and their eyes which lusted after idols). They shall loathe themselves because of their evil deeds, all their abominations.

10.verse: Then they shall know that it was not in vain that I, the LORD, threatened to inflict this calamity upon them.

11.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: Clap your hands, stamp your feet, and cry "Alas!" because of all the abominations of the house of Israel, for which they shall fall by the sword, by famine, and by pestilence.

12.verse: He that is far off shall die of pestilence, he that is near shall fall by the sword, and he that is besieged shall perish by famine; so will I spend my fury upon them.

13.verse: Then shall they know that I am the LORD, when their slain shall lie amid their idols, all about their altars, on every high hill and mountaintop, beneath every green tree and leafy oak, wherever they offered appeasing odors to any of their gods.

14.verse: I will stretch out my hand against them, and wherever they live I will make the land a desolate waste, from the desert to Riblah; thus shall they know that I am the LORD.

annotations.1: [3] High places: the sanctuaries on the mountaintops where illegal worship, whether of the Lord or of Canaanite deities, was performed.
annotations.2: [5] Scatter their bones . . . altars: dead men's bones defiled a place; cf 2 Kings 23:14
annotations.3: [11] Clap your hands, stamp your feet: here evidently signs of mourning; in Ezekiel 25:6, signs of joy
annotations.4: [13] Every green tree and leafy oak: sacred groves had a long history in Palestine as places of worship; cf Deut 12:2; note on Genesis 12:6
annotations.5: [14] From the desert to Riblah: the whole land, from the far south to the far north

1.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, prophesy against the prophets of Israel, prophesy! Say to those who prophesy their own thought: Hear the word of the LORD:

5.verse: You did not step into the breach, nor did you build a wall about the house of Israel that would stand firm against attack on the day of the LORD.

7.verse: Was not the vision you saw false, and your divination lying?

8.verse: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: Because you have spoken falsehood and have seen lying visions, therefore see! I am coming at you, says the Lord GOD.

10.verse: For the very reason that they led my people astray, saying, "Peace!" when there was no peace, and that, as one built a wall, they would cover it with whitewash,

11.verse: say then to the whitewashers: I will bring down a flooding rain; hailstones shall fall, and a stormwind shall break out.

12.verse: And when the wall has fallen, will you not be asked: Where is the whitewash you spread on?

13.verse: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: In my fury I will let loose stormwinds; because of my anger there shall be a flooding rain, and hailstones shall fall with destructive wrath.

14.verse: I will tear down the wall that you have whitewashed and level it to the ground, laying bare its foundations. When it falls, you shall be crushed beneath it; thus you shall know that I am the LORD.

15.verse: When I have spent my fury on the wall and its whitewashers, I tell you there shall be no wall, nor shall there be whitewashers -

16.verse: those prophets of Israel who prophesied to Jerusalem and saw for it visions of peace when there was no peace, says the Lord GOD.

3.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: Woe to those prophets who are fools, who follow their own spirit and have seen no vision.

4.verse: Like foxes among ruins are your prophets, O Israel!

6.verse: Their visions are false and their divination lying. They say, "Thus says the LORD!" though the LORD did not send them; then they wait for him to fulfill their word!

9.verse: But I will stretch out my hand against the prophets who have false visions and who foretell lies. They shall not belong to the community of my people, nor be recorded in the register of the house of Israel, nor enter the land of Israel; thus you shall know that I am the LORD.

17.verse: Now, son of man, turn toward the daughters of your people who prophesy their own thoughts; against these, prophesy: Thus says the Lord GOD:

22.verse: Because you have disheartened the upright man with lies when I did not wish him grieved, and have encouraged the wicked man not to turn from his evil conduct and save his life;

23.verse: therefore you shall no longer see false visions and practice divination, but I will rescue my people from your power. Thus you shall know that I am the LORD.

18.verse: Woe to those who sew bands for everyone's wrists and make veils for every size of head so as to entrap their owners. Do you think to entrap the lives of my people, yet keep yourselves alive?

19.verse: You dishonor me before my people with handfuls of barley and crumbs of bread, killing those who should not die and keeping alive those who should not live, lying to my people who willingly hear lies.

20.verse: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: See! I am coming at those bands of yours in which you entrap men's lives: I will tear them from their arms and set free those you have caught.

21.verse: I will tear off your veils and rescue my people from your power, so that they shall no longer be prey to your hands. Thus you shall know that I am the LORD.

annotations.1: [10] (10) To the confidence which the people had in their defenses against the Chaldeans, the false prophets contributed the illusion of security by predictions of peace, like men who whitewash a wall rather than allow its defects to be seen.
annotations.2: [18] (18) Sew bands . . . make veils: magical practices believed to give to the sorceresses power over those on whom they placed these objects
annotations.3: [19] (19) Handfuls of barley and crumbs of bread: used in divination and forecasting the future

1.verse: On the tenth day of the tenth month, in the ninth year, the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, write down this date today, for this very day the king of Babylon has invested Jerusalem.

3.verse: Propose this parable to the rebellious house: Thus says the Lord GOD: Set up the pot, set it up, then pour in some water.

4.verse: Put in it pieces of meat, all good pieces: thigh and shoulder; Fill it with the choicest joints

5.verse: taken from the pick of the flock. Then pile the wood beneath it; bring to a boil these pieces and the joints that are in it.

6.verse: Take out its pieces, one by one, without casting lots for it. Therefore, thus says the Lord GOD: Woe to the bloody city, a pot containing rust, whose rust has not been removed.

7.verse: For the blood she shed is in her midst; she poured it on the bare rock; she did not pour it out on the earth, to be covered with dust.

8.verse: To work up my wrath, to excite my vengeance, she put her blood on the bare rock, not to be covered.

9.verse: Therefore, thus says the Lord GOD: I, too, will heap up a great bonfire,

10.verse: piling on wood and kindling the fire, Till the meat has been cooked, till the broth has boiled.

11.verse: Then I will set the pot empty on the coals till its metal glows red hot, till the impurities in it melt, and its rust disappears.

12.verse: Yet not even with fire will its great rust be removed.

13.verse: Because you have sullied yourself with lewdness when I would have purified you, and you refused to be purified of your uncleanness, therefore you shall not be purified until I wreak my fury on you.

14.verse: I, the LORD, have spoken; it is coming, for I will bring it about without fail. I will not have pity nor repent. By your conduct and your deeds you shall be judged, says the Lord GOD.

15.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

16.verse: Son of man, by a sudden blow I am taking away from you the delight of your eyes, but do not mourn or weep or shed any tears.

17.verse: Groan in silence, make no lament for the dead, bind on your turban, put your sandals on your feet, do not cover your beard, and do not eat the customary bread.

18.verse: That evening my wife died, and the next morning I did as I had been commanded.

19.verse: Then the people asked me, "Will you not tell us what all these things that you are doing mean for us?" I therefore spoke to the people that morning,

20.verse: saying to them: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

21.verse: Say to the house of Israel: Thus says the Lord GOD: I will now desecrate my sanctuary, the stronghold of your pride, the delight of your eyes, the desire of your soul. The sons and daughters you left behind shall fall by the sword.

24.verse: Ezekiel shall be a sign for you: all that he did you shall do when it happens. Thus you shall know that I am the LORD.

22.verse: You shall do as I have done, not covering your beards nor eating the customary bread.

23.verse: Your turbans shall remain on your heads, your sandals on your feet. You shall not mourn or weep, but you shall rot away because of your sins and groan one to another.

25.verse: As for you, son of man, truly, on the day I take away from them their bulwark, their glorious joy, the delight of their eyes, the desire of their soul, and the pride of their hearts, their sons and daughters,

26.verse: that day the fugitive will come to you, that you may hear it for yourself;

27.verse: that day your mouth shall be opened and you shall be dumb no longer. Thus you shall be a sign to them, and they shall know that I am the LORD.

annotations.1: [1] The tenth day of the tenth month, in the ninth year: January 15, 588 B.C. The same date is given in Jeremiah 52:4.
annotations.2: [3-5] This present comparison of the inhabitants of Jerusalem to meat boiled in a pot symbolizes their punishment rather than their supposed protection as in Ezekiel 11:3
annotations.3: [7] Blood . . . to be covered with dust: since blood was sacred to God, it had to be covered with earth ( Lev 17:13); the blood of a murdered man that was left uncovered cried to heaven for vengeance; cf Job 16:18; Genesis 4:10
annotations.4: [17] The customary bread: eaten as a mourning observance; cf Jeremiah 16:7. The other gestures here forbidden were also popular mourning customs
annotations.5: [23-24] (22,23) The fall of the city will be so sudden and final that the exiles will have no time to go into mourning

1.verse: Then he brought me back to the entrance of the temple, and I saw water flowing out from beneath the threshold of the temple toward the east, for the facade of the temple was toward the east; the water flowed down from the southern side of the temple, south of the altar.

2.verse: He led me outside by the north gate, and around to the outer gate facing the east, where I saw water trickling from the southern side.

3.verse: Then when he had walked off to the east with a measuring cord in his hand, he measured off a thousand cubits and had me wade through the water, which was ankle-deep.

4.verse: He measured off another thousand and once more had me wade through the water, which was now knee-deep. Again he measured off a thousand and had me wade; the water was up to my waist.

5.verse: Once more he measured off a thousand, but there was now a river through which I could not wade; for the water had risen so high it had become a river that could not be crossed except by swimming.

6.verse: He asked me, "Have you seen this, son of man?" Then he brought me to the bank of the river, where he had me sit.

7.verse: Along the bank of the river I saw very many trees on both sides.

8.verse: He said to me, "This water flows into the eastern district down upon the Arabah, and empties into the sea, the salt waters, which it makes fresh.

9.verse: Wherever the river flows, every sort of living creature that can multiply shall live, and there shall be abundant fish, for wherever this water comes the sea shall be made fresh.

10.verse: Fishermen shall be standing along it from En-gedi to En-eglaim, spreading their nets there. Its kinds of fish shall be like those of the Great Sea, very numerous.

11.verse: Only its marshes and swamps shall not be made fresh; they shall be left for salt.

12.verse: Along both banks of the river, fruit trees of every kind shall grow; their leaves shall not fade, nor their fruit fail. Every month they shall bear fresh fruit, for they shall be watered by the flow from the sanctuary. Their fruit shall serve for food, and their leaves for medicine."

13.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: These are the boundaries within which you shall apportion the land among the twelve tribes of Israel (Joseph having two portions).

14.verse: All of you shall have a like portion in this land which I swore to give to your fathers, that it might fall to you as your inheritance.

15.verse: This is the boundary of the land on the north side: from the Great Sea in the direction of Hethlon, past Labo of Hamath, to Zedad,

16.verse: Berothah, and Sibraim, along the frontiers of Hamath and Damascus, to Hazar-enon which is on the border of the Hauran.

17.verse: Thus the border shall extend from the sea to Hazar-enon, with the frontier of Hamath and Damascus to the north. This is the northern boundary.

18.verse: The eastern boundary: between the Hauran - toward Damascus - and Gilead on the one side, and the land of Israel on the other side, the Jordan shall form the boundary down to the eastern sea as far as Tamar. This is the eastern boundary.

19.verse: The southern boundary: from Tamar to the waters of Meribath-kadesh, thence to the Wadi of Egypt, and on to the Great Sea. This is the southern boundary.

20.verse: The western boundary: the Great Sea forms the boundary up to a point parallel to Labo of Hamath. This is the western boundary.

21.verse: You shall distribute this land among yourselves according to the tribes of Israel.

22.verse: You shall allot it as inheritances for yourselves and for the aliens resident in your midst who have bred children among you. The latter shall be to you like native Israelites; along with you they shall receive inheritances among the tribes of Israel.

23.verse: In whatever tribe the alien may be resident, there you shall assign him his inheritance, says the Lord GOD.

annotations.1: [1-12] The wonderful and superabundant stream flowing from the temple, restoring to fertility traditionally arid ground, is symbolic of the return of the conditions of primeval paradise; cf Genesis 2:10-14. Water signifies great blessings, just as dryness signifies a curse; cf Ezekiel 26:5, 14.
annotations.2: [10] From En-gedi to En-eglaim: the former was about halfway down the western shore of the Dead Sea, the latter may have been at its northern extremity
annotations.3: [13-20] These boundaries of the restored Israel correspond to those of the Davidic kingdom at its fullest extent, the so-called "ideal boundaries" of the promised land; cf Numbers 34:3-12

1.verse: In the thirtieth year, on the fifth day of the fourth month, while I was among the exiles by the river Chebar, the heavens opened, and I saw divine visions. -

2.verse: On the fifth day of the month, the fifth year, that is, of King Jehoiachin's exile,

3.verse: the word of the LORD came to the priest Ezekiel, the son of Buzi, in the land of the Chaldeans by the river Chebar. - There the hand of the LORD came upon me.

4.verse: As I looked, a stormwind came from the North, a huge cloud with flashing fire (enveloped in brightness), from the midst of which (the midst of the fire) something gleamed like electrum.

5.verse: Within it were figures resembling four living creatures that looked like this: their form was human,

6.verse: but each had four faces and four wings,

7.verse: and their legs went straight down; the soles of their feet were round. They sparkled with a gleam like burnished bronze.

10.verse: Their faces were like this: each of the four had the face of a man, but on the right side was the face of a lion, and on the left side the face of an ox, and finally each had the face of an eagle.

9.verse: Their faces (and their wings) looked out on all their four sides; they did not turn when they moved, but each went straight forward.

12.verse: (Each went straight forward; wherever the spirit wished to go, there they went; they did not turn when they moved.)

8.verse: Human hands were under their wings, and the wings of one touched those of another.

11.verse: Each had two wings spread out above so that they touched one another's, while the other two wings of each covered his body.

13.verse: In among the living creatures something like burning coals of fire could be seen; they seemed like torches, moving to and fro among the living creatures. The fire gleamed, and from it came forth flashes of lightning.

15.verse: As I looked at the living creatures, I saw wheels on the ground, one beside each of the four living creatures.

16.verse: The wheels had the sparkling appearance of chrysolite, and all four of them looked the same: they were constructed as though one wheel were within another.

17.verse: They could move in any of the four directions they faced, without veering as they moved.

18.verse: The four of them had rims, and I saw that their rims were full of eyes all around.

19.verse: When the living creatures moved, the wheels moved with them; and when the living creatures were raised from the ground, the wheels also were raised.

20.verse: Wherever the spirit wished to go, there the wheels went, and they were raised together with the living creatures; for the spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels.

22.verse: Over the heads of the living creatures, something like a firmament could be seen, seeming like glittering crystal, stretched straight out above their heads.

23.verse: Beneath the firmament their wings were stretched out, one toward the other. (Each of them had two covering his body.)

24.verse: Then I heard the sound of their wings, like the roaring of mighty waters, like the voice of the Almighty. When they moved, the sound of the tumult was like the din of an army. (And when they stood still, they lowered their wings.)

26.verse: Above the firmament over their heads something like a throne could be seen, looking like sapphire. Upon it was seated, up above, one who had the appearance of a man.

27.verse: Upward from what resembled his waist I saw what gleamed like electrum; downward from what resembled his waist I saw what looked like fire; he was surrounded with splendor.

28.verse: Like the bow which appears in the clouds on a rainy day was the splendor that surrounded him. Such was the vision of the likeness of the glory of the LORD. When I had seen it, I fell upon my face and heard a voice that said to me:

annotations.1: [1] The thirtieth year, which corresponds to the fifth year of exile ( Ezekiel 1:2), has never been satisfactorily explained; possibly it refers to the prophet's age. The river Chebar: probably a canal near Nippur, southeast of Babylon, one of the sites on which the Jewish exiles were settled.
annotations.2: [2] The fifth day of the fourth month, the fifth year: July 31, 593 B.C.; cf Ezekiel 1:1
annotations.3: [4] The North: the abode of God; see notes on Job 37:22; Psalm 48:3. Electrum: an alloy of gold and silver, used here for some undetermined bright metal
annotations.4: [5] Four living creatures: identified as cherubim in Ezekiel 10:1-2(20-21)
annotations.5: [8-22] Note the changed order of the verses and the omission of the textually uncertain Ezekiel 1:14, 21. Such changes also occur elsewhere in this book
annotations.6: [22-23,26] This symbolic description of God's throne is similar to that in Exodus 24:9-10
annotations.7: [26] One who had the appearance of a man: God appearing in human form ( Ezekiel 1:28); cf Exodus 33:18-23

1.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, propose a riddle, and speak this proverb to the house of Israel:

3.verse: Thus speaks the Lord GOD: The great eagle, with great wings, with long pinions, with thick plumage, many-hued, came to Lebanon. He took the crest of the cedar,

4.verse: tearing off its topmost branch, And brought it to a land of tradesmen, set it in a city of merchants.

5.verse: Then he took some seed of the land, and planted it in a seedbed; A shoot by plentiful waters, like a willow he placed it,

6.verse: To sprout and grow up a vine, dense and low-lying, Its branches turned toward him, its roots lying under him. Thus it became a vine, produced branches and put forth shoots.

7.verse: But there was another great eagle, great of wing, rich in plumage; To him this vine bent its roots, sent out its branches, That he might water it more freely than the bed where it was planted.

8.verse: In a fertile field by plentiful waters it was planted, to grow branches, bear fruit, and become a majestic vine.

9.verse: Say: Thus says the Lord GOD: Can it prosper? Will he not rather tear it out by the roots and strip off its fruit, so that all its green growth will wither when he pulls it up by the roots? (No need of a mighty arm or many people to do this.)

10.verse: True, it is planted, but will it prosper? Will it not rather wither, when touched by the east wind, in the bed where it grew?

11.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

12.verse: Son of man, say now to the rebellious house: Do you not understand what this means? It is this: The king of Babylon came to Jerusalem and took away its king and princes with him to Babylon.

13.verse: Then he selected a man of the royal line with whom he made a covenant, binding him under oath, while removing the nobles of the land,

14.verse: so that the kingdom would remain a modest one, without aspirations, and would keep his covenant and obey him.

15.verse: But this man rebelled against him, sending envoys to Egypt to obtain horses and a great army. Can he prosper? Can he who does such things escape? Can he break a covenant and still go free?

16.verse: As I live, says the Lord GOD, in the home of the king who set him up to rule, whose oath he spurned, whose covenant with him he broke, there in Babylon I swear he shall die!

17.verse: When ramps are cast up and siege towers are built for the destruction of many lives, he shall not be saved in the conflict by Pharaoh with a great army and numerous troops.

18.verse: He spurned his oath, breaking his covenant. Though he gave his hand in pledge, he did all these things. He shall not escape!

19.verse: Therefore say: Thus says the Lord GOD: As I live, my oath which he spurned, my covenant which he broke, I swear to bring down upon his head.

20.verse: I will spread my net over him, and he shall be taken in my snare. I will bring him to Babylon and enter into judgment with him there over his breaking faith with me.

21.verse: All the crack troops among his forces shall fall by the sword, and the survivors shall be scattered in every direction. Thus you shall know that I, the LORD, have spoken.

22.verse: Therefore say: Thus says the Lord GOD: I, too, will take from the crest of the cedar, from its topmost branches tear off a tender shoot, And plant it on a high and lofty mountain;

23.verse: on the mountain heights of Israel I will plant it. It shall put forth branches and bear fruit, and become a majestic cedar. Birds of every kind shall dwell beneath it, every winged thing in the shade of its boughs.

24.verse: And all the trees of the field shall know that I, the LORD, Bring low the high tree, lift high the lowly tree, Wither up the green tree, and make the withered tree bloom. As I, the LORD, have spoken, so will I do.

annotations.1: [11-21] These verses explain the foregoing allegory. In 597 B.C., Nebuchadnezzar removed King Jehoiachin and took him into exile; in his place he set Zedekiah, Jehoiachin's uncle, on the throne and received from him the oath of loyalty. But Zedekiah was beguiled into rebellion by Pharaoh Hophra of Egypt, and thereby merited punishment; cf 2 Kings 24:10- 25:7.
annotations.2: [22-23] I, too, will take from the crest of the cedar . . . plant it: the Lord will restore Israel under a messianic King from the same Davidic dynasty

1.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, now say: Thus says the Lord GOD to the land of Israel: An end! The end has come upon the four corners of the land!

3.verse: Now the end is upon you; I will unleash my anger against you and judge you according to your conduct and lay upon you the consequences of all your abominations.

4.verse: I will not look upon you with pity nor have mercy; I will bring your conduct down upon you, and the consequences of your abominations shall be in your midst; then shall you know that I am the LORD.

5.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: Disaster upon disaster! See it coming!

6.verse: An end is coming, the end is coming upon you! See it coming!

7.verse: The climax has come for you who dwell in the land! The time has come, near is the day: a time of consternation, not of rejoicing.

8.verse: Soon now I will pour out my fury upon you and spend my anger upon you; I will judge you according to your conduct and lay upon you the consequences of all your abominations.

9.verse: I will not look upon you with pity nor have mercy; I will deal with you according to your conduct, and the consequences of your abominations shall be in your midst; then shall you know that it is I, the LORD, who strike.

10.verse: See, the day of the LORD! See, the end is coming! Lawlessness is in full bloom, insolence flourishes,

11.verse: violence has risen to support wickedness. It shall not be long in coming, nor shall it delay.

12.verse: The time has come, the day dawns. Let not the buyer rejoice nor the seller mourn, for wrath shall be upon all the throng.

13.verse: The seller shall not regain what he sold as long as he lives, for wrath shall be upon all the throng. Because of his sins, no one shall preserve his life.

14.verse: They shall sound the trumpet and make everything ready, yet no one shall go to war, for my wrath is upon all the throng.

15.verse: The sword is outside; pestilence and hunger are within. He that is in the country shall die by the sword; pestilence and famine shall devour those in the city.

16.verse: Even those who escape and flee to the mountains like the doves of the valleys - I will put them all to death, each one for his own sins.

17.verse: All their hands shall be limp, and all their knees shall run with water.

18.verse: They shall put on sackcloth, and horror shall cover them; shame shall be on all their faces and baldness on all their heads.

19.verse: They shall fling their silver into the streets, and their gold shall be considered refuse. Their silver and gold cannot save them on the day of the LORD'S wrath. They shall not be allowed to satisfy their craving or fill their bellies, for this has been the occasion of their sin.

20.verse: In the beauty of their ornaments they put their pride: they made of them their abominable images (their idols). For this reason I make them refuse.

21.verse: I will hand them over as booty to foreigners, to be spoiled and defiled by the wicked of the earth.

22.verse: I will turn away my face from them, and my treasure shall be profaned: robbers shall enter and profane it.

23.verse: They shall wreak slaughter, for the land is filled with bloodshed and the city full of violence.

24.verse: I will bring in the worst of the nations, who shall take possession of their houses. I will put an end to their proud strength, and their sanctuaries shall be profaned.

25.verse: When anguish comes they shall seek peace, but there will be none.

26.verse: There shall be disaster after disaster, rumor after rumor. Prophetic vision shall fade; instruction shall be lacking to the priest, and counsel to the elders,

27.verse: while the prince shall be enveloped in terror, and the hands of the common people shall tremble. I will deal with them according to their conduct, and according to their judgments I will judge them; thus they shall know that I am the LORD.

annotations.1: [12-13] Mundane affairs will cease to have any meaning in view of the disaster that is to come.

1.verse: On the twelfth day of the tenth month in the tenth year, the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, set your face against Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and prophesy against him and against all Egypt.

3.verse: Say this to him: Thus says the Lord GOD: See! I am coming at you, Pharaoh, king of Egypt, Great crouching monster amidst your Niles: Who say, "The Niles are mine; it is I who made them!"

4.verse: I will put hooks in your jaws and make the fish of your Niles stick to your scales, then draw you up from the midst of your Niles along with all the fish of your Niles sticking to your scales.

5.verse: I will cast you into the desert, you and all the fish of your Niles; You shall fall upon the open field, you shall not be taken up or buried; To the beasts of the earth and the birds of the air I give you as food,

6.verse: That all who dwell in Egypt may know that I am the LORD. Because you have been a reed staff for the house of Israel:

7.verse: When they held you in hand, you splintered, throwing every shoulder out of joint; When they leaned on you, you broke, bringing each one of them down headlong;

8.verse: therefore thus says the Lord GOD: See! I will bring the sword against you, and cut off from you both man and beast.

9.verse: The land of Egypt shall become a desolate waste; thus they shall know that I am the LORD. Because you said, "The Niles are mine; it is I who made them,"

10.verse: therefore see! I am coming at you and against your Niles; I will make the land of Egypt a waste and a desolation from Migdol to Syene, and even to the frontier of Ethiopia.

11.verse: No foot of man or beast shall pass through it; they shall not pass through it, and it will be uninhabited for forty years.

12.verse: I will make the land of Egypt the most desolate of lands, and its cities shall be the most deserted of cities for forty years; and I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations and strew them over foreign lands.

13.verse: Yet thus says the Lord GOD: At the end of forty years I will gather the Egyptians from the peoples among whom they are scattered,

14.verse: and I will restore Egypt's fortune, bringing them back to the land of Pathros, the land of their origin, where it will be the lowliest

15.verse: of kingdoms, never more to set itself above the nations. I will make them few, that they may not dominate the nations.

16.verse: No longer shall they be for the house of Israel to trust in, but the living reminder of its guilt for having turned to follow after them. Thus they shall know that I am the LORD.

17.verse: On the first day of the first month in the twenty-seventh year, the word of the LORD came to me:

18.verse: Son of man, Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, has led his army in an exhausting campaign against Tyre. Their heads became bald and their shoulders were galled; but neither he nor his army received any wages from Tyre for the campaign he led against it.

19.verse: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: I am now giving the land of Egypt to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon. He shall carry off its riches, plundering and pillaging it for the wages of his soldiers, who did it for me;

20.verse: as payment for his toil I have given him the land of Egypt, says the Lord GOD.

21.verse: On that day I will make a horn sprout for the house of Israel, and I will cause you to speak out in their midst; thus they shall know that I am the LORD.

annotations.1: [1] The twelfth day of the tenth month in the tenth year: January 7, 587 B.C. The siege of Jerusalem had begun a year earlier; cf Ezekiel 24:1.
annotations.2: [2] Egypt was allied with Judah against the Chaldeans
annotations.3: [3] Niles: the many rivulets of the Nile as it branches out into the Delta
annotations.4: [10] From Migdol to Syene: from the northern to the southern extremity of Egypt. Syene is the modern Assuan
annotations.5: [14] Pathros, the land of their origin: upper Egypt, that is, southern Egypt, where the Egyptians were thought to have originated; Isaiah 11:11; Jeremiah 44:1, 15
annotations.6: [17] The first day of the first month in the twenty-seventh year: April 26, 571 B.C. This is the latest date attached to any prophecy in Ezekiel
annotations.7: [18-19] The fulfillment of Ezekiel's prophecy against Tyre (Ezekial 26-28) was a thirteen-year siege of the city by Nebuchadnezzar (587-574 B.C.). Tyre seems to have been taken, but its resources were exhausted and the booty was small. Therefore Ezekiel now prophesies that Nebuchadnezzar will collect his wages as God's instrument in the punishment of Tyre, by plundering Egypt

1.verse: As for you, son of man, prophesy to the mountains of Israel: Mountains of Israel, hear the word of the LORD!

2.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: Because the enemy has said of you, "Ha! the everlasting heights have become our possession"

3.verse: (therefore prophesy in these words: Thus says the Lord GOD:); because you have been ridiculed and despised on all sides for having become a possession for the rest of the nations, and have become a byword and a popular jeer;

4.verse: therefore, mountains of Israel, hear the word of the LORD: (Thus says the Lord GOD to the mountains and hills, the ravines and valleys, the desolate ruins and abandoned cities, which have been given over to the pillage and mockery of the remaining nations round about;

5.verse: therefore thus says the Lord GOD:) Truly, with burning jealousy I speak against the rest of the nations (and against all of Edom) who with wholehearted joy and utter contempt have considered my land their possession to be delivered over to plunder.

6.verse: (Therefore, prophesy concerning the land of Israel, and say to the mountains and hills, the ravines and valleys: Thus says the Lord GOD:) With jealous fury I speak, because you have borne the reproach of the nations.

7.verse: Therefore do I solemnly swear that your neighboring nations shall bear their own reproach.

8.verse: As for you, mountains of Israel, you shall grow branches and bear fruit for my people Israel, for they shall soon return.

9.verse: See, I come to you, it is to you that I turn; you will be tilled and sown,

10.verse: and I will settle crowds of men upon you, the whole house of Israel; cities shall be repeopled, and ruins rebuilt.

11.verse: I will settle crowds of men and beasts upon you, to multiply and be fruitful. I will repeople you as in the past, and be more generous to you than in the beginning; thus you shall know that I am the LORD.

12.verse: (My people Israel are the ones whom I will have walk upon you; they shall take possession of you, and you shall be their heritage. Never again shall you rob them of their children.)

13.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: Because they have said of you, "You are a land that devours men, and you rob your people of their children";

14.verse: therefore, never again shall you devour men or rob your people of their children, says the Lord GOD.

15.verse: No more will I permit you to hear the reproach of nations, or bear insults from peoples, or rob your people of their children, says the Lord GOD.

16.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

17.verse: Son of man, when the house of Israel lived in their land, they defiled it by their conduct and deeds. In my sight their conduct was like the defilement of a menstruous woman.

18.verse: Therefore I poured out my fury upon them (because of the blood which they poured out on the ground, and because they defiled it with idols).

19.verse: I scattered them among the nations, dispersing them over foreign lands; according to their conduct and deeds I judged them.

20.verse: But when they came among the nations (wherever they came), they served to profane my holy name, because it was said of them: "These are the people of the LORD, yet they had to leave their land."

21.verse: So I have relented because of my holy name which the house of Israel profaned among the nations where they came.

22.verse: Therefore say to the house of Israel: Thus says the Lord GOD: Not for your sakes do I act, house of Israel, but for the sake of my holy name, which you profaned among the nations to which you came.

23.verse: I will prove the holiness of my great name, profaned among the nations, in whose midst you have profaned it. Thus the nations shall know that I am the LORD, says the Lord GOD, when in their sight I prove my holiness through you.

24.verse: For I will take you away from among the nations, gather you from all the foreign lands, and bring you back to your own land.

25.verse: I will sprinkle clean water upon you to cleanse you from all your impurities, and from all your idols I will cleanse you.

26.verse: I will give you a new heart and place a new spirit within you, taking from your bodies your stony hearts and giving you natural hearts.

27.verse: I will put my spirit within you and make you live by my statutes, careful to observe my decrees.

28.verse: You shall live in the land I gave your fathers; you shall be my people, and I will be your God.

29.verse: I will save you from all your impurities; I will order the grain to be abundant, and I will not send famine against you.

30.verse: I will increase the fruit on your trees and the crops in your fields; thus you shall no longer bear among the nations the reproach of famine.

31.verse: Then you shall remember your evil conduct, and that your deeds were not good; you shall loathe yourselves for your sins and your abominations.

32.verse: Not for your sakes do I act, says the Lord GOD - let this be known to you! Be ashamed and abashed because of your conduct, O house of Israel.

33.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: When I purify you from all your crimes, I will repeople the cities, and the ruins shall be rebuilt;

34.verse: the desolate land shall be tilled, which was formerly a wasteland exposed to the gaze of every passer-by.

35.verse: "This desolate land has been made into a garden of Eden," they shall say. "The cities that were in ruins, laid waste, and destroyed are now repeopled and fortified."

36.verse: Thus the neighboring nations that remain shall know that I, the LORD, have rebuilt what was destroyed and replanted what was desolate. I, the LORD, have promised, and I will do it.

37.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: This also I will be persuaded to do for the house of Israel: to multiply them like sheep.

38.verse: As with sacrificial sheep, the sheep of Jerusalem on its feast days, the cities which were in ruins shall be filled with flocks of men; thus they shall know that I am the LORD.

annotations.1: [20] The seventh day of the first month in the eleventh year: April 29, 587 B.C.
annotations.2: [21-26] This oracle was uttered during the siege of Jerusalem, which had now lasted more than a year ( Ezekiel 24:1). Pharaoh Hophra went to the aid of Jerusalem, causing the Chaldeans to lift the siege temporarily; cf Jeremiah 34:21; 37:6- 7. In the prophet's eyes, this was interfering with the divine punishment of Judah that was to be inflicted by the Chaldeans. The Egyptians were routed by the Chaldeans, and were able to offer no more help to Jerusalem; cf Ezekial 31

annotations.1: [9-12] Besides the land monopoly fostered by royal greed and collusion with the wealthy ( Micah 2:2; Isaiah 3:12-15; 5:8-10), one grave social evil of preexilic Israel was dishonesty in business; cf Hosea 12:8; Amos 8:5. Ephah: a dry measure; liquid measure: in Hebrew, a "bath," standardized according to the homer (a dry measure of about 10 bushels, or 80 gallons). In Ezekiel 45:12 reference is made to the change in value of the mina: before the exile it was valued at 50 shekels, but afterward, in imitation of Babylonian practice, the 60-shekel mina was adopted. The shekel was a unit of weight slightly less than half an ounce. As a monetary unit, the value obviously differed greatly, depending on whether it was a gold or a silver shekel.
annotations.2: [14] Kor: both a liquid and a dry measure, corresponding to the homer
annotations.3: [24] Hin: a sixth part of the liquid measure called a bath

2.verse: Then the word of the LORD came to me:

4.verse: Will you judge them? Will you judge, son of man? Make known to them the abominations of their ancestors
