6.verse: That day I swore to bring them out of the land of Egypt to the land I had scouted for them, a land flowing with milk and honey, a jewel among all lands.

7.verse: Then I said to them: Throw away, each of you, the detestable things that have held your eyes; do not defile yourselves with the idols of Egypt: I am the LORD, your God.

8.verse: But they rebelled against me and refused to listen to me; none of them threw away the detestable things that had held their eyes, they did not abandon the idols of Egypt. Then I thought of pouring out my fury on them and spending my anger on them there in the land of Egypt;

9.verse: but I acted for my name's sake, that it should not be profaned in the sight of the nations among whom they were, in whose presence I had made myself known to them, revealing that I would bring them out of the land of Egypt.

10.verse: Therefore I led them out of the land of Egypt and brought them into the desert.

11.verse: Then I gave them my statutes and made known to them my ordinances, which everyone must keep, to have life through them.

12.verse: I also gave them my sabbaths to be a sign between me and them, to show that it was I, the LORD, who made them holy.

13.verse: But the house of Israel rebelled against me in the desert. They did not observe my statutes, and they despised my ordinances that bring life to those who keep them. My sabbaths, too, they desecrated grievously. Then I thought of pouring out my fury on them in the desert to put an end to them,

14.verse: but I acted for my name's sake, that it should not be profaned in the sight of the nations in whose presence I had brought them out.

15.verse: Nevertheless I swore to them in the desert not to bring them to the land I had given them, a land flowing with milk and honey, a jewel among all lands.

16.verse: So much were their hearts devoted to their idols, they had not lived by my statutes, but despised my ordinances and desecrated my sabbaths.

17.verse: But I looked on them with pity, not wanting to destroy them, so I did not put an end to them in the desert.

18.verse: Then I said to their children in the desert: Do not observe the statutes of your parents or keep their ordinances; do not defile yourselves with their idols.

19.verse: I am the LORD, your God: observe my statutes and be careful to keep my ordinances;

20.verse: keep holy my sabbaths, as a sign between me and you to show that I am the LORD, your God.

21.verse: But their children rebelled against me: they did not observe my statutes or keep my ordinances that bring life to those who observe them, and my sabbaths they desecrated. Then I thought of pouring out my fury on them, of spending my anger on them in the desert;

22.verse: but I stayed my hand, acting for my name's sake, lest it be profaned in the sight of the nations in whose presence I brought them out.

23.verse: Nevertheless I swore to them in the desert that I would disperse them among the nations and scatter them over foreign lands;

24.verse: for they did not keep my ordinances, but despised my statutes and desecrated my sabbaths, with eyes only for the idols of their fathers.

25.verse: Therefore I gave them statutes that were not good, and ordinances through which they could not live.

26.verse: I let them become defiled by their gifts, by their immolation of every first-born, so as to make them an object of horror.

27.verse: Therefore speak to the house of Israel, son of man, and tell them: Thus says the Lord GOD: In this way also your fathers blasphemed me, breaking faith with me:

28.verse: when I had brought them to the land I had sworn to give them, and they saw all its high hills and leafy trees, there they offered their sacrifices (there they brought their offensive offerings), there they sent up appeasing odors, and there they poured out their libations.

29.verse: I asked them: To what sort of high place do you betake yourselves? - and so they call it a high place even to the present day.

30.verse: Therefore say to the house of Israel: Thus says the Lord GOD: Will you defile yourselves like your fathers? Will you lust after their detestable idols?

31.verse: By offering your gifts, by making your children pass through the fire, you defile yourselves with all your idols even to this day. Shall I let myself be consulted by you, house of Israel? As I live! says the Lord GOD: I swear I will not let myself be consulted by you.

32.verse: What you are thinking of shall never happen: "We shall be like the nations, like the peoples of foreign lands, serving wood and stone."

33.verse: As I live, says the Lord GOD, with a mighty hand and outstretched arm, with poured-out wrath, I swear I will be king over you!

34.verse: With a mighty hand and outstretched arm, with poured-out wrath, I will bring you out from the nations and gather you from the countries over which you are scattered;

35.verse: then I will lead you to the desert of the peoples, where I will enter into judgment with you face to face.

36.verse: Just as I entered into judgment with your fathers in the desert of the land of Egypt, so will I enter into judgment with you, says the Lord GOD.

37.verse: I will count you with the staff and bring back but a small number.

38.verse: I will separate from you those who have rebelled and transgressed against me; from the land where they sojourned as aliens I will bring them out, but they shall not return to the land of Israel. Thus you shall know that I am the LORD.

39.verse: As for you, house of Israel, thus says the Lord GOD: Come, each one of you, destroy your idols! Then listen to me, and never again profane my holy name with your gifts and your idols.

40.verse: For on my holy mountain, on the mountain height of Israel, says the Lord GOD, there the whole house of Israel without exception shall worship me; there I will accept them, and there I will claim your tributes and the first fruits of your offerings, and all that you dedicate.

41.verse: As a pleasing odor I will accept you, when I have brought you from among the nations and gathered you out of the countries over which you were scattered; and by means of you I will manifest my holiness in the sight of the nations.

42.verse: Thus you shall know that I am the LORD, when I bring you back to the land of Israel, the land which I swore to give to your fathers.

43.verse: There you shall recall your conduct and all the deeds by which you defiled yourselves; and you shall loathe yourselves because of all the evil things you did.

44.verse: And you shall know that I am the LORD when I deal with you thus, for my name's sake, and not according to your evil conduct and corrupt actions, O house of Israel, says the Lord GOD.

1.verse: On the first day of the. . . month in the eleventh year, the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, because of what Tyre said of Jerusalem: "Aha! it is broken, the gateway to the peoples; now that it is ruined, its wealth reverts to me!"

3.verse: therefore thus says the Lord GOD: See! I am coming at you, Tyre; I will churn up against you many nations, even as the sea churns up its waves;

4.verse: They shall destroy the walls of Tyre and raze her towers. I will scrape the ground from her and leave her a bare rock;

5.verse: She shall be a drying place for nets in the midst of the sea. I have spoken, says the Lord GOD: and she shall be booty for the nations.

6.verse: And her daughters on the mainland shall be slaughtered by the sword; thus they shall know that I am the LORD.

7.verse: For thus says the Lord GOD: I am now bringing up against Tyre from the north Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon, the king of kings, with horses and chariots, with cavalry and a great and mighty army.

8.verse: Your daughters on the mainland he shall slay with the sword; He shall place a siege tower against you, cast up a ramp about you, and raise his shields against you.

9.verse: He shall pound your walls with battering-rams and break down your towers with his weapons.

10.verse: The surge of his horses shall cover you with dust, amid the noise of steeds, of wheels and of chariots. Your walls shall shake as he enters your gates, even as one enters a city that is breached.

11.verse: With the hoofs of his horses he shall trample all your streets; Your people he shall slay by the sword; your mighty pillars he shall pull to the ground.

12.verse: Your wealth shall be plundered, your merchandise pillaged; Your walls shall be torn down, your precious houses demolished; Your stones, your timber, and your clay shall be cast into the sea.

13.verse: I will put an end to the noise of your songs, and the sound of your lyres shall be heard no more.

14.verse: I will make you a bare rock; a drying place for nets shall you be. Never shall you be rebuilt, for I have spoken, says the Lord GOD.

1.verse: Then he brought me to the nave and measured the pilasters, which were six cubits thick on either side.

3.verse: Then he went in beyond and measured the pilasters flanking that entrance, which were two cubits; the width of the entrance was six cubits, and the walls at either side of it extended seven cubits each.

4.verse: He measured the space beyond the nave, twenty cubits long and twenty cubits wide, and said to me, "This is the holy of holies."

5.verse: Then he measured the wall of the temple, which was six cubits thick; the side chambers, which extended all the way around the temple, had a width of four cubits.

7.verse: There was a broad circular passageway that led upward to the side chambers, for the temple was enclosed all the way around and all the way upward; therefore the temple had a broad way running upward so that one could pass from the lowest to the middle and the highest story.

8.verse: About the temple was a raised pavement completely enclosing it - the foundations of the side chambers - a full rod of six cubits in extent.

9.verse: The width of the outside wall which enclosed the side chambers was five cubits. Between the side chambers of the temple

17.verse: As high as the lintel of the door, even into the interior part of the temple as well as outside, on every wall on every side in both the inner and outer rooms were carved

1.verse: Then he brought me back to the outer gate of the sanctuary, facing the east; but it was closed.

2.verse: He said to me: This gate is to remain closed; it is not to be opened for anyone to enter by it; since the LORD, the God of Israel, has entered by it, it shall remain closed.

3.verse: Only the prince may sit down in it to eat his meal in the presence of the LORD. He must enter by way of the vestibule of the gate, and leave by the same way.

4.verse: Then he brought me by way of the north gate to the facade of the temple, and when I looked I saw the glory of the LORD filling the LORD'S temple, and I fell prone.

5.verse: Then he said to me: Son of man, pay strict attention, look carefully, and listen intently to all that I will tell you about the statutes and laws of the LORD'S temple; be attentive in regard to those who are to be admitted to the temple and all those who are to be excluded from the sanctuary.

6.verse: Say to that rebellious house, the house of Israel: Thus says the Lord GOD: Enough of all these abominations of yours, O house of Israel!

7.verse: You have admitted foreigners, uncircumcised both in heart and flesh, to my sanctuary to profane it when you offered me food, fat, and blood; thus you have broken my covenant by all your abominations.

8.verse: Instead of caring for the service of my temple, you have appointed such as these to serve me in my sanctuary in your stead.

9.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: No foreigners, uncircumcised in heart and in flesh, shall ever enter my sanctuary; none of the foreigners who live among the Israelites.

10.verse: But as for the Levites who departed from me when Israel strayed from me to pursue their idols, they shall bear the consequences of their sin.

11.verse: They shall serve in my sanctuary as gatekeepers and temple servants; they shall slaughter the holocausts and the sacrifices for the people, and they shall stand before the people to minister for them.

12.verse: Because they used to minister for them before their idols, and became an occasion of sin to the house of Israel, therefore I have sworn an oath against them, says the Lord GOD: they shall bear the consequences of their sin.

13.verse: They shall no longer draw near me to serve as my priests, nor shall they touch any of my sacred things, or the most sacred things. Thus they shall bear their disgrace because of all their abominable deeds.

14.verse: But I will set them to the service of the temple, for all its work and for everything that is to be done in it.

15.verse: As for the levitical priests, however, the Zadokites who cared for my sanctuary when the Israelites strayed from me, they shall draw near me to minister to me, and they shall stand before me to offer me fat and blood, says the Lord GOD.

16.verse: It is they who shall enter my sanctuary, they who shall approach my table to minister to me, and they who shall carry out my service.

17.verse: Whenever they enter the gates of the inner court, they shall wear linen garments; they shall not put on anything woolen when they minister at the gates of the inner court or within the temple.

18.verse: They shall have linen turbans on their heads and linen drawers on their loins; they shall not gird themselves with anything that causes sweat.

19.verse: When they are to go out to the people in the outer court, they shall take off the garments in which they ministered and leave them in the chambers of the sanctuary, putting on other garments; thus they will not transmit holiness to the people with their garments.

20.verse: They shall not shave their heads nor let their hair hang loose, but they shall keep their hair carefully trimmed.

21.verse: No priest shall drink wine when he is to enter the inner court.

22.verse: They shall not take for their wives either widows or divorced women, but only virgins of the race of Israel; however, they may marry women who are the widows of priests.

23.verse: They shall teach my people to distinguish between the sacred and the profane, and make known to them the difference between the clean and the unclean.

24.verse: In capital cases they shall stand as judges, judging them according to my decrees. They shall observe my laws and statutes on all my festivals, and keep my sabbaths holy.

25.verse: They shall not make themselves unclean by coming near any dead person, unless it be their father, mother, son, daughter, brother, or maiden sister; for these they may make themselves unclean.

26.verse: After a priest has been cleansed, he must wait an additional seven days,

27.verse: and on the day he enters the inner court to minister in the sanctuary, he shall present his sin offering, says the Lord GOD.

28.verse: They shall have no inheritance, for I am their inheritance; you shall give them no property in Israel, for I am their property.

29.verse: They shall eat the cereal offering, the sin offering, and the guilt offering; whatever is under the ban in Israel shall be theirs.

30.verse: All the choicest first fruits of every kind, and all the best of your offerings of every kind, shall belong to the priests; likewise the best of your dough you shall give to the priests to bring a blessing down upon your house.

31.verse: The priests shall not eat anything, whether flesh or fowl, that has died of itself or has been killed by wild beasts.

annotations.1: [3] The prince stands at the eastern gate of the inner court while his sacrifice is offered up ( Ezekiel 46:2); he then goes to the vestibule of the outer court, there to partake of his sacrificial meal. The closed outer gate on the eastern side signifies that the Lord has entered the temple permanently, not to depart again.
annotations.2: [7-9] In the preexilic temple various menial services had been performed by foreigners; cf Joshua 9:22-27. In the new temple the Levites will perform these services ( Ezekiel 44:10-14)
annotations.3: [10-14] Levites other than the Zadokite priesthood of Jerusalem had performed priestly functions at the various sanctuaries and high places in Israel and Judah, where the worship of the Lord had often been corrupted with pagan elements. The demotion of the Levites to menial service in the temple was enforced in the actual restoration after the exile, and explains why relatively few Levites were willing to return; cf Ezra 8:15-17
annotations.4: [19] Thus they will not transmit holiness to the people: holiness was thought of as something physical, as though it were communicable, and therefore not to be brought in contact with unconsecrated persons
annotations.5: [29] Under the ban: dedicated to the Lord, withdrawn from profane use

1.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, there were two women, daughters of the same mother,

3.verse: who even as young girls played the harlot in Egypt. There the Egyptians caressed their bosoms and fondled their virginal breasts.

4.verse: Oholah was the name of the elder, and the name of her sister was Oholibah. They became mine and bore sons and daughters. (As for their names: Samaria is Oholah, and Jerusalem is Oholibah.)

5.verse: Oholah became a harlot faithless to me; she lusted after her lovers, the Assyrians, warriors

6.verse: dressed in purple, governors and officers, all of them attractive young men, knights mounted on horses.

7.verse: Thus she gave herself as a harlot to them, to all the elite of the Assyrians, and she defiled herself with all those for whom she lusted (with all their idols).

8.verse: She did not give up the harlotry which she had begun in Egypt, when they had lain with her as a young girl, fondling her virginal breasts and pouring out their impurities on her.

9.verse: Therefore I handed her over to her lovers, the Assyrians for whom she had lusted.

10.verse: They exposed her nakedness, her sons and daughters they took away, and herself they slew with the sword. Thus she became a byword for women, for they punished her grievously.

11.verse: Though her sister Oholibah saw all this, her lust was more depraved than her sister's, and she outdid her in harlotry.

12.verse: She too lusted after the Assyrians, governors and officers, warriors impeccably clothed, knights mounted on horses, all of them attractive young men.

13.verse: I saw that she had defiled herself. Both had gone down the same path,

14.verse: yet she went further in her harlotry. When she saw men drawn on the wall, the images of Chaldeans drawn with vermillion,

15.verse: with sashes girded about their waists, flowing turbans on their heads, all looking like chariot warriors, the portraits of Babylonians, natives of Chaldea,

16.verse: she lusted for them; no sooner had she set eyes on them than she sent messengers to them in Chaldea.

17.verse: Then the Babylonians came to her, to the love couch, and defiled her with their intercourse. As soon as she was defiled by them, she became disgusted with them.

18.verse: Her harlotry was discovered and her shame was revealed, and I became disgusted with her as I had become disgusted with her sister.

19.verse: But she played the harlot all the more, recalling the days of her girlhood, when she had been a harlot in the land of Egypt.

20.verse: She lusted for the lechers of Egypt, whose members are like that of an ass, and whose heat is like that of stallions.

21.verse: You yearned for the lewdness of your girlhood, when the Egyptians fondled your breasts, caressing your bosom.

22.verse: Therefore, Oholibah, thus says the Lord GOD: I will now stir up your lovers against you, those with whom you are disgusted, and I will bring them against you from every side:

23.verse: the men of Babylon and all of Chaldea, Pekod, Shoa and Koa, along with all those of Assyria, attractive young men, all of them governors and officers, charioteers and warriors, all of them horsemen.

24.verse: They shall come against you from the north with chariots and wagons and many peoples. Shields, bucklers, and helmets they shall array against you everywhere.

29.verse: They shall deal with you in hatred, seizing all that you have worked for and leaving you stark naked, so that your indecent nakedness is exposed. Your lewdness and harlotry

31.verse: Because you followed in the path of your sister, I will hand you her cup.

33.verse: Filled with destruction and grief, a cup of dismay, the cup of your sister.

34.verse: You shall drain it dry, and gnaw at the very sherds of the cup, and you shall tear out your breasts; for I have spoken, says the Lord GOD.

35.verse: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: Because you have forgotten me and cast me behind your back, it is for you to bear the penalty of your lewdness and harlotry.

37.verse: For they committed adultery, and blood is on their hands. They committed adultery with their idols; to feed them they immolated the children they had borne me.

38.verse: (This, too, they did to me: they defiled my sanctuary and desecrated my sabbaths.

39.verse: On the very day they slew their children for their idols, they entered my sanctuary to desecrate it. Thus they acted within my house.)

40.verse: Moreover, they sent for men who had to come from afar, to whom messengers were sent. And so they came - and for them you bathed yourself, painted your eyes, and put on ornaments.

41.verse: You sat on a couch prepared for them, with a table spread before it, on which you had set my incense and oil.

42.verse: Then was heard the shout of a carefree mob in the city, and these were men brought in from the desert, who put bracelets on the women's arms and splendid diadems on their heads.

43.verse: So I said: "Oh, this woman jaded with adulteries! Now they will commit whoredom with her, and as for her. . . ."

44.verse: And indeed they did come to her as men come to a harlot. Thus they came to Oholah and Oholibah, the lewd women.

45.verse: But just men shall punish them with the sentence meted out to adulteresses and murderesses, for they have committed adultery, and blood is on their hands.

46.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: Summon an assembly against them, and deliver them over to terror and plunder.

47.verse: The assembly shall stone them and hack them to pieces with their swords. They shall slay their sons and daughters, and burn their houses with fire.

48.verse: Thus I will put an end to lewdness in the land, and all the women will be warned not to imitate your lewdness.

49.verse: They shall inflict on you the penalty of your lewdness, and you shall pay for your sins of idolatry. Thus you shall know that I am the LORD

annotations.1: [4] Oholah . . . Oholibah: symbolic names. The first, standing for Samaria, may be read to mean "her own tent"; the latter, standing for Jerusalem, means "My tent is in her." The references seem to be to the schismatic temple and cult of the Lord in Samaria, as opposed to their authentic counterpart in Jerusalem.
annotations.2: [23] Pekod, Shoa and Koa: peoples living about the Tigris, part of "greater Babylonia.&quot
annotations.3: [40] Men who had to come from afar: ambassadors from Assyria and Babylon. Alliances with these countries aided in the corruption of both Israel and Judah

1.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, speak thus to your countrymen: When I bring the sword against a country, and the people of this country select one of their number to be their watchman,

3.verse: and the watchman, seeing the sword coming against the country, blows the trumpet to warn the people,

4.verse: anyone hearing but not heeding the warning of the trumpet and therefore slain by the sword that comes against him, shall be responsible for his own death.

5.verse: He heard the trumpet blast yet refused to take warning; he is responsible for his own death, for had he taken warning he would have escaped with his life.

6.verse: But if the watchman sees the sword coming and fails to blow the warning trumpet, so that the sword comes and takes anyone, I will hold the watchman responsible for that person's death, even though that person is taken because of his own sin.

7.verse: You, son of man, I have appointed watchman for the house of Israel; when you hear me say anything, you shall warn them for me.

8.verse: If I tell the wicked man that he shall surely die, and you do not speak out to dissuade the wicked man from his way, he (the wicked man) shall die for his guilt, but I will hold you responsible for his death.

9.verse: But if you warn the wicked man, trying to turn him from his way, and he refuses to turn from his way, he shall die for his guilt, but you shall save yourself.

10.verse: As for you, son of man, speak to the house of Israel: You people say, "Our crimes and our sins weigh us down; we are rotting away because of them. How can we survive?"

11.verse: Answer them: As I live, says the Lord GOD, I swear I take no pleasure in the death of the wicked man, but rather in the wicked man's conversion, that he may live. Turn, turn from your evil ways! Why should you die, O house of Israel?

12.verse: As for you, son of man, tell your countrymen: The virtue which a man has practiced will not save him on the day that he sins; neither will the wickedness that a man has done bring about his downfall on the day that he turns from his wickedness (nor can the virtuous man, when he sins, remain alive).

13.verse: Though I say to the virtuous man that he shall surely live, if he then presumes on his virtue and does wrong, none of his virtuous deeds shall be remembered; because of the wrong he has done, he shall die.

14.verse: And though I say to the wicked man that he shall surely die, if he turns away from his sin and does what is right and just,

15.verse: giving back pledges, restoring stolen goods, living by the statutes that bring life, and doing no wrong, he shall surely live, he shall not die.

16.verse: None of the sins he committed shall be held against him; he has done what is right and just, he shall surely live.

17.verse: Yet your countrymen say, "The way of the LORD is not fair!"; but it is their way that is not fair.

18.verse: When a virtuous man turns away from what is right and does wrong, he shall die for it.

19.verse: But when a wicked man turns away from wickedness and does what is right and just, because of this he shall live.

20.verse: And still you say, "The way of the LORD is not fair!"? I will judge every one of you according to his ways, O house of Israel.

21.verse: On the fifth day of the tenth month, in the twelfth year of our exile, the fugitive came to me from Jerusalem and said, "The city is taken!"

22.verse: The hand of the LORD had come upon me the evening before the fugitive arrived, and he opened my mouth when the fugitive reached me in the morning. My mouth was opened, and I was dumb no longer.

23.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

24.verse: Son of man, they who live in the ruins on the land of Israel reason thus: "Abraham, though but a single individual, received possession of the land; we, therefore, being many, have as permanent possession the land that has been given to us."

25.verse: Give them this answer: Thus says the Lord GOD: You eat on the mountains, you raise your eyes to your idols, you shed blood - yet you would keep possession of the land?

26.verse: You rely on your sword, you do abominable things, each one of you defiles his neighbor's wife - yet you would keep possession of the land?

27.verse: Tell them this: Thus says the Lord GOD: As I live, those who are in the ruins I swear shall fall by the sword; those who are in the open field I have given to the wild beasts for food; and those who are in fastnesses and in caves shall die by the plague.

28.verse: I will make the land a desolate waste, so that its proud strength will come to an end, and the mountains of Israel shall be so desolate that no one will cross them.

29.verse: Thus they shall know that I am the LORD, when I make the land a desolate waste because of all the abominable things they have done.

30.verse: As for you, son of man, your countrymen are talking about you along the walls and in the doorways of houses. They say to one another, "Come and hear the latest word that comes from the LORD."

31.verse: My people come to you as people always do; they sit down before you and hear your words, but they will not obey them, for lies are on their lips and their desires are fixed on dishonest gain.

32.verse: For them you are only a ballad singer, with a pleasant voice and a clever touch. They listen to your words, but they will not obey them.

33.verse: But when it comes - and it is surely coming!-they shall know that there was a prophet among them.

annotations.1: [21-22] January 8, 585 B.C. According to Jeremiah ( Ezekiel 39:2), Jerusalem was taken in July, 587. Some MSS read "eleventh" for twelfth year (January, 586); even so, there was ample time between the fall of Jerusalem and the arrival of the fugitive from that city to journey to Babylon. However, this is the fugitive sent to fulfill the promise of Ezekiel 24:25, 27, the eye witness who would release Ezekiel from his dumbness; cf Ezekiel 3:26-27.
annotations.2: [23-29] News brought by the fugitive furnished the occasion of this prophecy. Like Jeremiah, Ezekiel rejects the idea that the survivors in Judah have any claim to the land. The new Israel is to be formed from the exiles
annotations.3: [30] The fulfillment of Ezekiel's prophecies about Jerusalem was responsible for this temporary enthusiasm among the unstable people

1.verse: As for you, son of man, take a sharp sword and use it like a barber's razor, passing it over your head and beard. Then take a set of scales and divide the hair you have cut.

2.verse: Burn a third in the fire, within the city, when the days of your siege are completed; place another third around the city and strike it with the sword; the final third strew in the wind, and pursue it with the sword.

3.verse: (But of the last take a small number and tie them in the hem of your garment.

4.verse: Then take some of these and throw them in the midst of the fire and burn them.) Say to the whole house of Israel:

5.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: This is Jerusalem! In the midst of the nations I placed her, surrounded by foreign countries.

6.verse: But she rebelled against my ordinances more wickedly than the nations, and against my statutes more than the foreign countries surrounding her; she has spurned my ordinances and has not lived by my statutes.

7.verse: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: Because you have been more rebellious than the nations surrounding you, not living by my statutes nor fulfilling my ordinances, but acting according to the ordinances of the surrounding nations;

8.verse: therefore thus says the Lord GOD: See, I am coming at you! I will inflict punishments in your midst while the nations look on.

9.verse: Because of all your abominations I will do with you what I have never done before, the like of which I will never do again.

10.verse: This means that fathers within you shall eat sons, and sons shall eat fathers. I will inflict punishments upon you and scatter all that remain of your people in every direction.

11.verse: Therefore, as I live, says the Lord GOD, because you have defiled my sanctuary with all your detestable abominations, I swear to cut you down. I will not look upon you with pity nor have mercy.

12.verse: A third of your people shall die of pestilence and perish of hunger within you; another third shall fall by the sword all around you; and a third I will scatter in every direction, and I will pursue them with the sword.

16.verse: When I loose against you the cruel, destructive arrows of hunger, I will break your staff of bread;

17.verse: I will send famine against you, and wild beasts that shall rob you of your children. Pestilence and bloodshed shall stalk through you, and I will bring the sword upon you. I, the LORD, have spoken!

13.verse: Thus shall my anger spend itself, and I will wreak my fury upon them till I am appeased; they shall know that I, the LORD, have spoken in my jealousy when I spend my fury upon them.

14.verse: I will make you a waste and a reproach among the nations that surround you, which every passer-by may see.

15.verse: When I execute judgment upon you in anger and fury and with furious chastisements, you shall be a reproach and an object of scorn, a terrible warning to the nations that surround you. I, the LORD, have spoken!

annotations.1: [2] The city: the one drawn on the tablet.
annotations.2: [8] I am coming at you: an expression borrowed from the language of warfare in which enemies attacked one another with the sword. You in Ezekiel 5:8-17 is Jerusalem
annotations.3: [10] Fathers . . . shall eat sons, and sons . . . fathers: see note on Lam 2:20

1.verse: When certain elders of Israel came and sat down before me,

2.verse: the word of the LORD came to me:

3.verse: Son of man, these men have the memory of their idols fresh in their hearts, and they keep the occasion of their sin before them. Why should I allow myself to be consulted by them?

4.verse: Therefore speak with them, and say to them: Thus says the Lord GOD: If anyone of the house of Israel, holding the memory of his idols in his heart and keeping the occasion of his sin before him, has recourse to a prophet, I, the LORD, will be his answer in person because of his many idols.

5.verse: Thus would I bring back to their senses the house of Israel, who have become estranged from me through all their idols.

6.verse: Therefore say to the house of Israel: Thus says the Lord GOD: Return and be converted from your idols; turn yourselves away from all your abominations.

7.verse: For if anyone of the house of Israel or any alien resident in Israel is estranged from me, and holds the memory of his idols in his heart and keeps the occasion of his sin before him, yet asks a prophet to consult me for him, I, the LORD, will be his answer in person.

8.verse: I will turn against that man, and make of him an example and a byword. I will cut him off from the midst of my people. Thus you shall know that I am the LORD.

9.verse: As for the prophet, if he is beguiled into speaking a word, I, the LORD, shall have beguiled that prophet; I will stretch out my hand against him and root him out of my people Israel.

10.verse: Each shall receive punishment for his sin, the inquirer and the prophet shall be punished alike,

11.verse: so that the house of Israel may no longer stray from me and may no longer be defiled by all their sins. Thus they shall be my people, and I will be their God, says the Lord GOD.

12.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

13.verse: Son of man, when a land sins against me by breaking faith, I stretch out my hand against it and break its staff of bread, I let famine loose upon it and cut off from it both man and beast;

14.verse: and even if these three men were in it, Noah, Daniel, and Job, they could save only themselves by their virtue, says the Lord GOD.

15.verse: If I were to cause wild beasts to prowl the land, depopulating it so that it became a waste, traversed by none because of the wild beasts,

16.verse: and these three men were in it, as I live, says the Lord GOD, I swear they could save neither sons nor daughters; they alone would be saved, and the land would be a waste.

17.verse: Or if I brought the sword upon this country, commanding the sword to pass through the land cutting off from it man and beast,

18.verse: and these three men were in it, as I live, says the Lord GOD, they would be unable to save either sons or daughters; they alone would be saved.

19.verse: Or if I were to send pestilence into this land, pouring out upon it my bloodthirsty fury, cutting off from it man and beast,

20.verse: even if Noah, Daniel, and Job were in it, as I live, says the Lord GOD, I swear that they could save neither son nor daughter; they would save only themselves by their virtue.

21.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: Even though I send Jerusalem my four cruel punishments, the sword, famine, wild beasts, and pestilence, to cut off from it man and beast,

22.verse: still some survivors shall be left in it who will bring out sons and daughters; when they come out to you, you shall see their conduct and their actions and be consoled regarding the evil I have brought on Jerusalem (all that I have brought upon it).

23.verse: They shall console you when you see their conduct and actions, for you shall then know that it was not without reason that I did to it what I did, says the Lord GOD.

annotations.1: [9] I, the LORD, shall have beguiled that prophet: the ancient Israelites attributed to God every action, good or evil; cf 1 Sam 18:10; 2 Sam 24:1-3. We would say, rather, that God permitted this deceit.
annotations.2: [12-23] The doctrine of personal responsibility before God was not new (cf Ezekiel 3:16-21; 18; 33:1-20); but it had not been emphasized by the prophets before the exile, who mostly predicted national retribution and called for national repentance
annotations.3: [14] Noah, Daniel, and Job: proverbially virtuous men. The Daniel named here may be the traditional just judge of the ancient past, celebrated in Canaanite literature, who is possibly reflected in Daniel 13, but is not the hero of Daniel 1-12

22.verse: Then the cherubim lifted their wings, and the wheels went along with them, while up above them was the glory of the God of Israel.

23.verse: And the glory of the LORD rose from the city and took a stand on the mountain which is to the east of the city.

1.verse: Spirit lifted me up and brought me to the east gate of the temple. At the entrance of the gate I saw twenty-five men, among whom were Jaazaniah, son of Azzur, and Pelatiah, son of Benaiah, princes of the people.

2.verse: The LORD said to me: Son of man, these are the men who are planning evil and giving wicked counsel in this city.

3.verse: "Shall we not," they say, "be building houses soon? The city is the kettle, and we are the meat."

4.verse: Therefore prophesy against them, son of man, prophesy!

5.verse: Then the spirit of the LORD fell upon me, and he told me to say: Thus says the LORD: This is the way you talk, house of Israel, and what you are plotting I well know.

6.verse: You have slain many in this city and have filled its streets with your slain.

7.verse: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: Your slain whom you have placed within it, they are the meat, and the city is the kettle; but you I will take out of it.

8.verse: You fear the sword, but the sword I will bring upon you, says the Lord GOD.

9.verse: I will bring you out of the city, and hand you over to foreigners, and inflict punishments upon you.

10.verse: By the sword you shall fall; at the boundaries of Israel I will judge you; thus you shall know that I am the LORD.

11.verse: The city shall not be a kettle for you, nor shall you be the meat within it. At the boundaries of Israel I will judge you,

12.verse: and you shall know that I am the LORD, by whose statutes you have not lived, and whose ordinances you have not kept; rather, you have acted according to the ordinances of the nations around you.

13.verse: While I was prophesying, Pelatiah, the son of Benaiah, died. I fell prone and cried out in a loud voice: "Alas, Lord GOD! will you utterly wipe out what remains of Israel?"

14.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

15.verse: Son of man, it is about your kinsmen, your fellow exiles, and the whole house of Israel that the inhabitants of Jerusalem say, "They are far away from the LORD; to us the land of Israel has been given as our possession."

16.verse: Therefore say: Thus says the Lord GOD: Though I have removed them far among the nations and scattered them over foreign countries - and was for a while their only sanctuary in the countries to which they had gone -

17.verse: I will gather you from the nations and assemble you from the countries over which you have been scattered, and I will restore to you the land of Israel.

18.verse: They shall return to it and remove from it all its detestable abominations.

19.verse: I will give them a new heart and put a new spirit within them; I will remove the stony heart from their bodies, and replace it with a natural heart,

20.verse: so that they will live according to my statutes, and observe and carry out my ordinances; thus they shall be my people and I will be their God.

21.verse: But as for those whose hearts are devoted to their detestable abominations, I will bring down their conduct upon their heads, says the Lord GOD.

annotations.1: [22-23] These verses have been transposed from Ezekial 11.
annotations.2: [3] These words reflect the false confidence of the inhabitants of Jerusalem in the face of the Chaldean invasion. Jerusalem, they think, is like an iron kettle protecting the meat within it from harm; but cf Ezekiel 24:3-6
annotations.3: [15-21] Like Jeremiah (cf Ezekial 29), Ezekiel knows that no reform is to be expected from the men of Judah who remained in Palestine; but the exiles will be the ones to form the new Israel. The new, spiritual covenant will replace the former covenant; cf Jeremiah 24:7

1.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: As for you, son of man, utter a lament over Tyre,

3.verse: and say to Tyre that is situated at the approaches of the sea, that brought the trade of the peoples to many a coastland: Thus says the Lord GOD: Tyre, you said, "I am a ship, perfect in beauty."

4.verse: In the midst of the sea your builders placed you, perfected your beauty.

5.verse: With cypress from Senir they built for you all of your decks; Cedar from Lebanon they took to make you a mast;

6.verse: From the highest oaks of Bashan they made your oars; Your bridge they made of cypress wood from the coasts of Kittim.

7.verse: Fine embroidered linen from Egypt became your sail (to serve you as a banner). Purple and scarlet from the coasts of Elishah covered your cabin.

8.verse: Citizens of Sidon and Arvad served as your oarsmen; Skilled men of Zemer were in you to be your mariners;

9.verse: The elders and experts of Gebal were in you to caulk your seams. Every ship and sailor on the sea came to you to carry trade.

10.verse: Persia and Lud and Put were in your army as warriors; shield and helmet they hung upon you, increasing your splendor.

11.verse: The men of Arvad were all about your walls, and the Gamadites were in your towers; they hung their bucklers all around on your walls, and made perfect your beauty.

12.verse: Tarshish traded with you, so great was your wealth, exchanging silver, iron, tin, and lead for your wares.

13.verse: Javan, Tubal, and Meshech were also traders with you, exchanging slaves and articles of bronze for your goods.

14.verse: From Beth-togarmah horses, steeds, and mules were exchanged for your wares.

15.verse: The Rhodanites trafficked with you; many coastlands traded with you; ivory tusks and ebony wood they gave you for payment.

16.verse: Edom traded with you, so many were your products, exchanging garnets, purple, embroidered cloth, fine linen, coral, and rubies for your wares.

17.verse: Judah and the land of Israel trafficked with you, exchanging Minnith wheat, figs, honey, oil, and balm for your goods.

18.verse: Damascus traded with you, so great was your wealth, exchanging Helbon wine and Zahar wool.

19.verse: Javan exchanged wrought iron, cassia, and aromatic cane from Uzal for your wares.

20.verse: Dedan traded with you for riding gear.

21.verse: The trade of Arabia and of all the sheikhs of Kedar belonged to you; they dealt in lambs, rams, and goats.

22.verse: The merchants of Sheba and Raamah also traded with you, exchanging for your wares the very choicest spices, all kinds of precious stones, and gold.

23.verse: Haran, Canneh, and Eden, the merchants of Sheba, Asshur, and Chilmad

24.verse: traded with you, marketing with you rich garments, violet mantles, embroidered cloth, varicolored carpets, and firmly woven cords.

25.verse: Ships of Tarshish journeyed for you in your merchandising. You were full and heavily laden in the heart of the sea.

26.verse: Through the deep waters your oarsmen brought you home, But the east wind smashed you in the heart of the sea.

27.verse: Your wealth, your goods, your wares, your sailors, and your crew, (the caulkers of your seams, those who traded for your goods, all your warriors who were in you, and all the great crowd within you) Sank into the heart of the sea on the day of your shipwreck.

28.verse: Hearing the shouts of your mariners, the shores begin to quake.

29.verse: Down from their ships come all who ply the oar; The sailors, all the mariners of the sea, stand on the shore,

30.verse: Making their voice heard on your behalf, shouting bitter cries, Strewing dust on their heads, rolling in the ashes.

31.verse: For you they shave their heads and put on sackcloth, For you they weep in anguish, with bitter lament.

32.verse: In their mourning they utter a lament over you; thus they wail over you: Who was ever destroyed like Tyre in the midst of the sea?

33.verse: With your goods which you drew from the seas you filled many peoples; With your great wealth and merchandise you enriched the kings of the earth.

34.verse: Now you are wrecked in the sea, in the watery depths; Your wares and all your crew have gone down with you.

35.verse: All who dwell on the coastlands are aghast over you, Their kings are terrified, their faces convulsed.

36.verse: The traders among the peoples now hiss at you; You have become a horror, and you shall be no more

annotations.1: [5] Senir: another name for Mount Hermon; cf Deut 3:9.
annotations.2: [6] Bashan: northern Transjordan, which, like Lebanon, was noted for its great forests. Kittim: probably Cyprus
annotations.3: [7] Elishah: probably another term for Cyprus
annotations.4: [8-9] Sidon . . . Arvad . . . Zemer . . . Gebal: Phoenician cities in Tyre's orbit of influence; the last-named is the classical Byblos

1.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, make known to Jerusalem her abominations.

3.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD to Jerusalem: By origin and birth you are of the land of Canaan; your father was an Amorite and your mother a Hittite.

4.verse: As for your birth, the day you were born your navel cord was not cut; you were neither washed with water nor anointed, nor were you rubbed with salt, nor swathed in swaddling clothes.

5.verse: No one looked on you with pity or compassion to do any of these things for you. Rather, you were thrown out on the ground as something loathsome, the day you were born.

6.verse: Then I passed by and saw you weltering in your blood. I said to you: Live in your blood

7.verse: and grow like a plant in the field. You grew and developed, you came to the age of puberty; your breasts were formed, your hair had grown, but you were still stark naked.

8.verse: Again I passed by you and saw that you were now old enough for love. So I spread the corner of my cloak over you to cover your nakedness; I swore an oath to you and entered into a covenant with you; you became mine, says the Lord GOD.

9.verse: Then I bathed you with water, washed away your blood, and anointed you with oil.

10.verse: I clothed you with an embroidered gown, put sandals of fine leather on your feet; I gave you a fine linen sash and silk robes to wear.

11.verse: I adorned you with jewelry: I put bracelets on your arms, a necklace about your neck,

12.verse: a ring in your nose, pendants in your ears, and a glorious diadem upon your head.

13.verse: Thus you were adorned with gold and silver; your garments were of fine linen, silk, and embroidered cloth. Fine flour, honey, and oil were your food. You were exceedingly beautiful, with the dignity of a queen.

14.verse: You were renowned among the nations for your beauty, perfect as it was, because of my splendor which I had bestowed on you, says the Lord GOD.

15.verse: But you were captivated by your own beauty, you used your renown to make yourself a harlot, and you lavished your harlotry on every passer-by, whose own you became.

16.verse: You took some of your gowns and made for yourself gaudy high places, where you played the harlot. . . .

17.verse: You took the splendid gold and silver ornaments that I had given you and made for yourself male images, with which also you played the harlot.

18.verse: You took your embroidered gowns to cover them; my oil and my incense you set before them;

19.verse: the food that I had given you, the fine flour, the oil, and the honey with which I fed you, you set before them as an appeasing odor, says the Lord GOD.

20.verse: The sons and daughters you had borne me you took and offered as sacrifices to be devoured by them! Was it not enough that you had become a harlot?

21.verse: You slaughtered and immolated my children to them, making them pass through fire.

22.verse: And through all your abominations and harlotries you remembered nothing of when you were a girl, stark naked and weltering in your blood.

23.verse: Then after all your evildoing - woe, woe to you! says the Lord GOD -

24.verse: you raised for yourself a platform and a dais in every public place.

25.verse: At every street corner you built a dais for yourself to use your beauty obscenely, spreading your legs for every passer-by, playing the harlot countless times.

26.verse: You played the harlot with the Egyptians, your lustful neighbors, so many times that I was provoked to anger.

27.verse: Therefore I stretched out my hand against you, I diminished your allowance and delivered you over to the will of your enemies, the Philistines, who revolted at your lewd conduct.

28.verse: You also played the harlot with the Assyrians, because you were not satisfied; and after playing the harlot with them, you were still not satisfied.

29.verse: Again and again you played the harlot, now going to Chaldea, the land of the traders; but despite this, you were still not satisfied.

30.verse: How wild your lust! says the Lord GOD, that you did all these things, acting like a shameless prostitute,

31.verse: building your platform at every street corner and erecting your dais in every public place! Yet you were unlike a prostitute, since you disdained payment.

32.verse: The adulterous wife receives, instead of her husband, payment.

33.verse: All harlots receive gifts. But you rather bestowed your gifts on all your lovers, bribing them to come to you from all sides for your harlotry.

34.verse: Thus in your harlotry you were different from all other women. No one sought you out for prostitution. Since you gave payment instead of receiving it, how different you were!

35.verse: Therefore, harlot, hear the word of the LORD!

36.verse: Thus says the Lord GOD: Because you poured out your lust and revealed your nakedness in your harlotry with your lovers and abominable idols, and because you sacrificed the life-blood of your children to them,

37.verse: I will now gather together all your lovers whom you tried to please, whether you loved them or loved them not; I will gather them against you from all sides and expose you naked for them to see.

38.verse: I will inflict on you the sentence of adulteresses and murderesses; I will wreak fury and jealousy upon you.

39.verse: I will hand you over to them to tear down your platform and demolish your dais; they shall strip you of your garments and take away your splendid ornaments, leaving you stark naked.

40.verse: They shall lead an assembly against you to stone you and hack you with their swords.

41.verse: They shall burn your apartments with fire and inflict punishments on you while many women look on. Thus I will put an end to your harlotry, and you shall never again give payment.

42.verse: When I have wreaked my fury upon you I will cease to be jealous of you, I will be quiet and no longer vexed.

43.verse: Because you did not remember what happened when you were a girl, but enraged me with all these things, therefore in return I am bringing down your conduct upon your head, says the Lord GOD. For did you not add lewdness to the rest of your abominable deeds?

44.verse: See, everyone who is fond of proverbs will say of you, 'Like mother, like daughter.'

45.verse: Yes, you are the true daughter of the mother who spurned her husband and children, and you are a true sister to those who spurned their husbands and children - your mother was a Hittite and your father an Amorite.

46.verse: Your elder sister was Samaria with her daughters, living to the north of you; and your younger sister, living to the south of you, was Sodom with her daughters.

47.verse: Yet not only in their ways did you walk, and act as abominably as they did; in a very short time you became more corrupt in all your ways than they.

48.verse: As I live, says the Lord GOD, I swear that your sister Sodom, with her daughters, has not done as you and your daughters have done!

49.verse: And look at the guilt of your sister Sodom: she and her daughters were proud, sated with food, complacent in their prosperity, and they gave no help to the poor and needy.

50.verse: Rather, they became haughty and committed abominable crimes in my presence; then, as you have seen, I removed them.

51.verse: Samaria did not commit half your sins! You have done more abominable things than they, and have even made your sisters appear just, with all the abominable deeds you have done.

52.verse: You, then, bear your shame; you are an argument in favor of your sisters! In view of your sinful deeds, more abominable than theirs, they appear just in comparison with you. Blush for shame, and bear the shame of having made your sisters appear just.

53.verse: I will restore their fortunes, the fortune of Sodom and her daughters and of Samaria and her daughters (and I will restore your fortune along with them),

54.verse: that you may bear your shame and be disgraced for all the comfort you brought them.

55.verse: Yes, your sisters, Sodom and her daughters, Samaria and her daughters, shall return to their former state (you and your daughters shall return to your former state).

56.verse: Was not your sister Sodom kept in bad repute by you while you felt proud of yourself,

57.verse: before your wickedness became evident? Now you are like her, reproached by the Edomites and all your neighbors, despised on all sides by the Philistines.

58.verse: The penalty of your lewdness and your abominations - you must bear it all, says the LORD.

59.verse: For thus speaks the Lord GOD: I will deal with you according to what you have done, you who despised your oath, breaking a covenant.

60.verse: Yet I will remember the covenant I made with you when you were a girl, and I will set up an everlasting covenant with you.

61.verse: Then you shall remember your conduct and be ashamed when I take your sisters, those older and younger than you, and give them to you as daughters, even though I am not bound by my covenant with you.

62.verse: For I will re-establish my covenant with you, that you may know that I am the LORD,

63.verse: that you may remember and be covered with confusion, and that you may be utterly silenced for shame when I pardon you for all you have done, says the Lord GOD.

annotations.1: [ 40:1- 48:35] This lengthy vision of the new Israel is dated ( Ezekiel 40:1) April 28, 573 B.C. It is largely concerned with the new temple and the prescriptions to govern it, but other details of the restored commonwealth are included, forming a kind of program for the future. The literary form of the vision has been aptly termed "utopian": it is plain that the prophet did not expect a literal fulfillment of much of what he described. The passage doubtless underwent successive additions, both from the prophet and from later inspired writers.
annotations.2: [5] A cubit and a handbreadth: the ordinary cubit consisted of six handbreadths; the great cubit, of seven. In measuring the temple, a rod six great cubits long was used. The ordinary cubit was about one and a half feet, or, more exactly, 17.5 inches; the large cubit, 20.4 inches
annotations.3: [6-16] The east gate, leading into the outer court of the temple, is described more fully than the north and south gates, which, however, were of the same dimensions. On the west side of the outer court there was a large building instead of a gate ( Ezekiel 41:12)
annotations.4: [17] The outer court: the court outside the temple area proper, which had its own inner court ( Ezekiel 40:28-37)
annotations.5: [28-37] The gates leading into the inner court of the temple area correspond to the gates leading into the outer court, with the exception that their vestibules are on the outer rather than the inner side. (Ezekiel 40:30, a dittography of Ezekiel 40:29 is omitted.
annotations.6: [46] The Zadokites: descendants of the priestly line of Zadok; cf 2 Sam 15:24-29; 1 Kings 1:32-34; 2:35
annotations.7: [ 40:48- 41:15] The description of Ezekiel's visionary temple closely follows the description of the temple of Solomon (1 Kings 6)
annotations.8: [ 40:49- 41:4] Vestibule . . . nave . . . holy of holies: the three divisions of the temple building in progressing order of sanctity. The last is called "the inner sanctuary" in 1 Kings 6

verses.1:
Ezekiel
Introduction
Ezekiel's complex character makes him one of the most interesting figures in Israelite prophecy. In many ways he resembles the more primitive type of prophet represented by Elijah and Elisha; yet he clearly depends on all his predecessors in prophecy, and his teaching is a development of theirs. His unique contribution to the history of prophetism lies in his manifest interest in the temple and the liturgy, an interest paralleled in no other prophet - not even Jeremiah who, like Ezekiel, was also a priest. Particularly because of this interest, Ezekiel's influence on postexilic religion was enormous, and not without reason has he been called "the father of Judaism." This has resulted in his prophecies reaching us with the evident marks of editing and addition by the post-exilic circles that shared his intense interest. However, we may be sure that in this book we have throughout what is in substance the prophet's own work
Ezekiel became a prophet in Babylon - the first prophet to receive the call to prophesy outside the Holy Land. As one of the exiles deported by Nebuchadnezzar in 597, his first task was to prepare his fellow countrymen in Babylon for the final destruction of Jerusalem, which they believed to be inviolable. Accordingly, the first part of his book consists of reproaches for Israel's past and present sins and the confident prediction of yet a further devastation of the land of promise and a more general exile. In 587, when Nebuchadnezzar destroyed Jerusalem, Ezekiel was vindicated before his unbelieving compatriots
After this time, Ezekiel's message changes. From now on his prophecy is characterized by the promise of salvation in a new covenant, and he is anxious to lay down the conditions necessary to obtain it. Even as Jeremiah had believed, Ezekiel thought that the exiles were the hope of Israel's restoration, once God's allotted time for the Exile had been accomplished. His final eight chapters are an utopian vision of the Israel of the future, rid of its past evils and reestablished firmly under the rule of the Lord. The famous vision of the dry bones in chapter 37 expresses his firm belief in a forthcoming restoration, Israel rising to new life from the graveyard of Babylon. But Ezekiel's new covenant, like Jeremiah's, was to see its true fulfillment only in the New Testament
Perhaps no other prophet has stressed the absolute majesty of God as Ezekiel does. This appears not only in the tremendous vision by the river Chebar with which his prophecy opens, but throughout the book. Ultimately, says Ezekiel, whatever God does to or for man is motivated by zeal for his own holy name. The new heart and the new spirit which must exist under the new covenant cannot be the work of man; they too must be the work of God. By such teachings he helped prepare for the New Testament doctrine of salvation through grace
The Book of Ezekiel is divided as follows
I. Call of the Prophet ( Ezekiel 1:1- 3:27)
II. Before the Siege of Jerusalem ( Ezekiel 4:1- 24:27)
III. Prophecies against Foreign Nations ( Ezekiel 25:1- 32:32)
IV. Salvation for Israel ( Ezekiel 33:1- 39:29)
V. The New Israel ( Ezekiel 40:1- 48:35)

3.verse: Spirit lifted me up in the air and brought me in divine visions to Jerusalem, to the entrance of the north gate, where stood the statue of jealousy which stirs up jealousy.

5.verse: He said to me: Son of man, look toward the north! I looked toward the north and saw northward of the gate the altar of the statue of jealousy.

6.verse: Son of man, he asked me, do you see what they are doing? Do you see the great abominations that the house of Israel is practicing here, so that I must depart from my sanctuary? But you shall see still greater abominations!

7.verse: Then he brought me to the entrance of the court, where I saw there was a hole in the wall.

8.verse: Son of man, he ordered, dig through the wall. I dug through the wall and saw a door.

9.verse: Enter, he said to me, and see the abominable evils which they are doing here.

10.verse: I entered and saw that all around upon the wall were pictured the figures of all kinds of creeping things and loathsome beasts (all the idols of the house of Israel).

11.verse: Before these stood seventy of the elders of the house of Israel, among whom stood Jaazaniah, son of Shaphan, each of them with his censer in his hand, and the fragrance of the incense was rising upward.

12.verse: Then he said to me: Do you see, son of man, what each of these elders of the house of Israel is doing in his idol room? They think: "The LORD cannot see us; the LORD has forsaken the land."

13.verse: He continued: You shall see still greater abominations that they are practicing.

14.verse: Then he brought me to the entrance of the north gate of the temple, and I saw sitting there the women who were weeping for Tammuz.

15.verse: Then he said to me: Do you see this, son of man? You shall see other abominations, greater than these!

16.verse: Then he brought me into the inner court of the LORD'S house, and there at the door of the LORD'S temple, between the vestibule and the altar, were about twenty-five men with their backs to the LORD'S temple and their faces toward the east; they were bowing down to the sun.

17.verse: Do you see, son of man? he asked me. Is it such a trivial matter for the house of Judah to do the abominable things they have done here - for they have filled the land with violence, and again and again they have provoked me - that now they must also put the branch to my nose?

18.verse: Therefore I in turn will act furiously: I will not look upon them with pity nor will I show mercy.

annotations.1: [3] The statue of jealousy which stirs up jealousy: the statue which provokes the Lord's jealousy for his honor. This was probably the statue of the goddess Asherah erected by the wicked King Manasseh (cf 2 Kings 21:7; 2 Chron 33:7, 15). Though it had been removed by King Josiah ( 2 Kings 23:6), it had no doubt been set up again in the repaganizing of Jerusalem that followed on Josiah's death.
annotations.2: [5] He: an angel accompanies Ezekiel in these visions and represents the voice of the Lord; cf Ezekiel 40:3-4
annotations.3: [10] Creeping things and loathsome beasts: probably Egyptian deities, which were represented in animal form. During the last days of Jerusalem King Zedekiah was allied with Egypt, trusting in it for protection against the Chaldeans
annotations.4: [14] Weeping for Tammuz: the withering of trees and plants in autumn was thought to be due to the descent of Tammuz, the Babylonian god of fertility, to the nether world of the dead; this descent was bewailed by the women
annotations.5: [16] Bowing down to the sun: sun worship had been made an important part of Judahite idolatry by the impious kings; cf 2 Kings 23:11
annotations.6: [17] Put the branch to my nose: the meaning is uncertain. Perhaps it refers to an Egyptian practice imported into Judah: the Egyptian sun god Re is pictured with a vine branch at his nose, signifying the transfer of creative power (divine breath) to living things. Such rites were abominable to the Lord

1.verse: Thus the word of the LORD came to me:

2.verse: Son of man, what makes the wood of the vine better than any other wood? That branch among the trees of the forest!

3.verse: Can you use its wood to make anything worthwhile? Can you make even a peg from it, to hang on it any kind of vessel?

4.verse: If you throw it on the fire as fuel and the fire devours both ends and even the middle is scorched, is it still good for anything?

5.verse: Why, even when it was whole it was good for nothing; how much less, when the fire has devoured and scorched it, can it be used for anything!

6.verse: Therefore, thus says the Lord GOD: Like the wood of the vine among the trees of the forest, which I have destined as fuel for the fire, do I make the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

7.verse: I will set my face against them; they have escaped from the fire, but the fire shall devour them. Thus you shall know that I am the LORD, when I turn my face against them.

8.verse: I will make the land a waste, because they have broken faith, says the Lord GOD.
